DT Article
TI FIRST RECORD OF THE GENUS PARABELBELLA BULANOVA-ZACHVATKINA (ORIBATIDA,
   DAMAEIDAE) FROM CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Xie, Li-Xia
   Yan, Yi
   Yang, Mao-Fa (yangmaofa@sohu.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 277-281
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Parabelbella Bulanova-Zachvatkina, 1967 is reported for the
   first time with a new species P. dimidiaspina sp. nov. from Beishan
   National Forest Park, Huzhu County, Xining, Qinghai Province, China. All
   specimens examined are deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou
   University, Guiyang, China (GUGC).
C1 Yang, Mao-Fa; Guizhou Univ, Inst Entomol, Guiyang, 550025, China, China.
EM yangmaofa@sohu.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Parabelbella [China /  / New record]. 
   Parabelbella dimidiaspina [Qinghai /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Parabelbella (Acari): [New record]. 
   Parabelbella dimidiaspina (Acari): [Sp nov, Qinghai, P. 277].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS HAEMOLAELAPS FROM NINGXIA, CHINA (ACARI,
   LAELAPIDAE).
AU Bai, Xue-Li
   Yan, Yi
   Gao, Xue-Ping
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 286-288
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Haemolaelaps jindaochaoi sp. nov. is described form mites collected from
   the body of bettle family Silphidae in Pingluo County, Ningxia of China.
   Type specimens are deposited in the Collection of the Medical Entomology
   of Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology Academy of Military
   Medical Science, Beijing, China and the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region
   Center for Disease Prevention and Control, Yinchuan, China.
C1 Bai, Xue-Li; Ningxia Hua Autonomous Reg Ctr Dis Control & Prev,
   Yinchuan, 750004, China, China.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   associate species] [Ningxia Hui /  / New species; coleopteran
   associate]. 
   Silphidae [Associations / Haemolaelaps jindaochaoi (Arachnida) / New
   associate species] [Ningxia Hui /  / New associated arachnid species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Beetles; Chelicerates; Insects; Invertebrates

   Staphylinoidea
OR Haemolaelaps jindaochaoi (Acari): [Sp nov, Ningxia Hui, Associated with
   Silphidae (Coleoptera), p. 287]. 
   Silphidae (Staphylinoidea).

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS TOMOCERUS (COLLEMBOLA, TOMOCERIDAE) FROM

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tomocerus jiuzhaiensis, a new species of the genus Tomocerus
   (Collembola, Tomoceridae) from Sichuan Province, China is described. All
   the type specimens of the new species are deposited in the Insect
   Collection College of Life and Engineering,Southwest University of
   Science and Technology.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS ERGATETTIX KIRBY FROM ZHEJIANG, CHINA
   (ORTHOPTERA, TETRIGOIDEA, TETRIGIDAE).
AU Yin, Xiang-Chu (yxch@hbu.edu.cn) 
   Su, Lan
   Yin, Zhan
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 293-295
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Ergatettix Kirby, 1914, namely E.
   zhejiangensis sp. nov. from Zhejiang of China is described in this
   paper. The new species is similar to E. dorsifera (Walker, 1871), but
   differs from the latter by: width of vertex larger than diameter of eye;
   frontal ridge with parallel carinae on both sides; median carina of
   pronotum waved distinctly, with 8 waves and length of hind femur is 3. 0
   time maximum width. The type specimens are deposited in College Life
   Sciences, Hebei University, Baoding, China. Holotype [male], paratype 1
   [female], Zhejiang, Cixi (30[degree]18'N, 121[degree] 08' E), 27 Apr.
   2010, collected by SU Lan. Etymology. The specific epithet is named for
   Zhejiang, the type locality.
C1 Yin, Xiang-Chu; Hebei Univ, Coll Life Sci, Baoding, 071002, China,
   China.
EM yxch@hbu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ergatettix zhejiangensis [Zhejiang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Ergatettix dorsifera - (Walker 1871) (Saltatoria): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 295]. 
   Ergatettix zhejiangensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Zhejiang, P. 293]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15005023861
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15005023862
DT Article
TI ONE NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS SAUSSURELLA BOLIVAR (ORTHOPTERA,
   TETRIGOIDEA) FROM XIZANG, CHINA.
AU Zheng, Zhe-Min
   Lin, Li-Liang
   Shi, Fu-Ming
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 296-299
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper,one new species of the genus Saussurella is
   described, i. e. S. xizangensis sp. nov. The new species is allied to S.
   indica Hancock, 1912 and S. decurva Br. -W.,1893,but differs from the
   latter two species in: 1) AP/T (the length of pronotum divided by the
   length of tegmina) ratio 2. 35; 2) with a pair short oblique
   longitudinal keels between shoulders; 3) tegmen oval; 4) the part of
   hind wing which surpassing the top of posterior pronotal process about 2
   mm; 5) genicular denticles very large; 6) antennae black. It also
   differs from S. decurva by the middle lobe of subgenital plate of female
   surpassing the lateral lobes and differs from S. longipotera (Yin) by
   the anterior pronotal process strongly decurved at apex; [female],
   subgenital plate with median lobe elongate, its tip exceeding lateral
   lobes posteriorly. [female] Length of body 12. 0 - 12. 5 mm; length of
   pronotum 17. 0 - 17. 2 mm; length of hind femur 6. 0 - 6. 5 mm. Holotype
   [female], Xizang, Motuo (29[degree] 2' N, 95[degree]5'E), 31 Oct. 2011,
   collected by ZHAO Le-Hong. Paratype 1[female], same data as holotype.
   Type specimens are kept in the Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal
   University. Etymology. The specific epithet is named for the type
   locality.
C1 Zheng, Zhe-Min; Shaanxi Normal Univ, Inst Zool, Xian, 710062, China,
   China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Saussurella xizangensis [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Saussurella - Bolivar 1887 (Saltatoria): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 298; Key to species, P. 297]. 
   Saussurella xizangensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 297]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15005023862
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS FORMOSATETTIX TINKHAM FROM SICHUAN, CHINA
   (ORTHOPTERA, TETRIGOIDEA, TETRIGIDAE).
AU Lin, Min-Ping
   Wei, Shi-Zhen
   Deng, Wei-An
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 300-302
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Formosatettix Tinkham, F. nigrimaculatus sp.
   nov. is described from Lushan, Xichang, Sichuan, China. The new species
   is similar to F. xianggelila Zheng et Ou, 2004 and F. gonggashanensis
   Zheng, 1992 but differs in: vertex 1. 3 times width of an eye; vertex
   and frontal ridge forming obtuse-rounded in profile; frontal costa not
   concave between lateral ocelli; lower margins of middle femora straight.
   The type specimens are deposited in the Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi
   Normal University, Xi'an, China.
C1 Lin, Min-Ping; Guangxi Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Guilin, 541004,
   China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Formosatettix nigrimaculatus [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Formosatettix nigrimaculatus (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 300]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15005023863
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS MICROPEPLUS LATREILLE FROM SICHUAN, CHINA
   (COLEOPTERA, STAPHYLINIDAE, MICROPEPLINAE).
AU Zheng, Fa-Ke
   Yan, Xiang-Hui
   Li, Yu-Jie
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 303-306
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Micropeplus Latreille is described under the
   name of Micropeplus xiaoae sp. nov., with color photos of habitus, head,
   pronotum, elytra, metasternum, 3rd to 7th tergites of abdomen, 8th
   sternite, and aedeagus provided. The new species was found in the dead
   weeds of the Yele Nature Reserve, Mianning County, Sichuan, China. A key
   to the Chinese species of the genus is provided. Type specimens are
   deposited in the Life Science College, China West Normal University,
   Sichuan.
C1 Zheng, Fa-Ke; China West Normal Univ, Life Sci Coll, Nanchong, 637002,
   China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Micropeplus [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Micropeplus xiaoae [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Micropeplidae
OR Micropeplus - Latreille 1809 (Micropeplidae): [Key to species, China, P.
   303]. 
   Micropeplus xiaoae (Micropeplidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 304].

TI PAHAMUNAYA SCHMID, A NEW GENUS RECORD FROM CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF A
   NEW SPECIES (TRICHOPTERA, POLYCENTROPODIDAE).
AU Zhong, Hua
   Yang, Lian-Fang (lfyang@njau.edu.cn) 
   Morse, John C.
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 307-310
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Pahamunaya Schmid, 1958 is recorded for the first time from
   China, and a new species Pah. sinensis sp. nov. from Southern China is
   described and figured. The type specimens are deposited in the Insect
   Collection of Nanjing Agricultural University, China.

   210095, China, China.

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC STUDY OF THE GENUS ECPYRRHORRHOE HUBNER (LEPIDOPTERA,
   CRAMBIDAE, PYRAUSTINAE) FROM CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF THREE NEW
   SPECIES.
AU Gao, Qiang
   Zhang, Dan-Dan
   Wang, Shu-Xia (shxwang@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 311-316
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Ecpyrrhorrhoe Hubner is further studied in China. Three new
   species are described: E. aduncis sp. nov., E. multispinalis sp. nov.
   and E. angustivalvaris sp. nov. Photographs of adults and illustrations
   of genitalia are provided. Keys to all the known Chinese species are
   given based on the male and female genitalia respectively, and a map to
   show the geographical distribution of Ecpyrrhorrhoe in China is
   included.
C1 Wang, Shu-Xia; Nankai Univ, Coll Life Sci, Tianjin, 300071, China,
   China.
EM shxwang@nankai.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ecpyrrhorrhoe [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe aduncis [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe angustivalvaris [Guizhou /  / New species]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe multispinalis [Anhui /  / New species] [Shanxi /  / ]
   [Tianjin /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae
OR Ecpyrrhorrhoe - Huebner 1825 (Pyralidae): [Key to species, China, Male
   genitalia, p.311, female genitalia, p. 312]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe aduncis (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 312]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe angustivalvaris (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, Guizhou, P. 314]. 
   Ecpyrrhorrhoe multispinalis (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, Tianjin, P. 312].

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC STUDY OF THE GENUS DIPLOLEPIS GEOFFROY (HYMENOPTERA,
   CYNIPIDAE, DIPLOLEPIDINI) IN CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF THREE NEW
   SPECIES.
AU Wang, Yi-Ping
   Guo, Rui
   Liu, Zhi-Wei
   Chen, Xue-Xin
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 317-327
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Diplolepis Geoffroy (Hymenoptera, Cynipidae,
   Diplolepidini) from China are revised and five species are recognized,
   including three new species (Diplolepis flaviabdomenis sp. nov.,
   Diplolepis hunanensis sp. nov. and Diplolepis minoriabdomenis sp. nov.),
   which are described and illustrated in this paper with key to Chinese
   species of Diplolepis. The type material is deposited in the Parasitic
   Hymenoptera Collection, Zhejiang A & F University, Hangzhou China, and
   Department of Biology from Eastern Illinois University, Illinois,
   America.
C1 Wang, Yi-Ping; Zhejiang Agr & Forest Univ, Coll Forest & Biotechnol,
   Linan, 311300, China, China.
RI Chen, Xue-xin/D-1592-2010
OI Chen, Xue-xin/0000-0002-9109-8853
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Diplolepis [China /  / Key to species] [ /  / Systematics]. 
   Diplolepis flaviabdomenis; Diplolepis minoriabdomenis [Zhejiang /  / New
   species]. 
   Diplolepis hunanensis [Hunan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae

   Diplolepis flaviabdomenis (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Zhejiang, P. 321]. 
   Diplolepis hunanensis (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Hunan, P. 323]. 
   Diplolepis minoriabdomenis (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Zhejiang, P. 324].

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF MACROPHYA KOREANA SUBGROUP OF MACROPHYA SANGUINOLENTA
   GROUP (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) FROM CHINA.
AU Wei, Mei-Cai (weimc@126.com) 
   Xu, Yi
   Li, Ze-Jian
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 328-334
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Macrophya dabieshanica Wei et Xu, sp. nov. and Macrophya liui Wei et Li,
   sp. nov., two new species of Tenthredininae from China are described. A
   key to known species of M. koreana subgroup of Macrophya sanguinolenta
   group is provided. The division of the subgroups of Macrophya
   sanguinolenta group, as well as the known species of Macrophya
   sanguinolenta group from Palaearctic and North Oriental Regions, is
   briefly discussed. A new group is proposed for the 5 European species:
   M. diaphenia Benson, 1968, M. postica (Bridle, 1832), M. rufipes (L.,
   1758), M. superba Tischbein, 1852 and M. diversipes (Schrank, 1782).
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Cent South Forestry Univ, Lab Insect Systemat &
   Evolutionary Biol, Changsha, Hunan, 410004, China, China.
EM weimc@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Macrophya dabieshanica [Anhui /  / New species]. 
   Macrophya liui [Henan /  / New species] [Hubei /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Symphyta, Tenthredinoidea,
   Tenthredinidae
OR Macrophya dabieshanica - Wei & Xu 2013 (Tenthredinidae): [Sp nov, Anhui,
   P. 329]. 
   Macrophya koreana subgroup (Tenthredinidae): [New species group, P. 329;
   Key to species, P. 333]. 
   Macrophya liui - Wei & Li 2013 (Tenthredinidae): [Sp nov, Henan, P.
   328]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15005023868

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF OBSOLETA AND MESOMELA GROUPS OF TENTHREDO LINNAEUS
   (HYMENOPTERA, TENTHREDINIDAE) FROM CHINA.
AU Liu, Meng-Meng
   Li, Ze-Jian
   Wei, Mei-Cai (liummy2012@163.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 335-342
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of obsoleta-mesomela group of Tenthredo from China are
   described: Tenthredo paraobsoleta Wei et Liu, sp. nov. and Tenthredo
   pseudomesomela Wei et Li, sp. nov. The former belongs to obsoleta
   subgroup and the latter belongs to mesomela subgroup. The type specimens
   of two new species are deposited in the Insect Collection of Central
   South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan, China.
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Cent South Univ Forestry & Technol, Lab Insect Systemat &
   Evolutionary Biol, Changsha, Hunan, 410000, China, China.

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS TENTHREDO LINNAEUS (HYMENOPTERA,
   TENTHREDINIDAE) FROM CHINA.
AU Hu, Ping
   Wei, Mei-Cai (hupingcs@163.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 343-350
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species from China are described: Tenthredo flatotrunca Wei et
   Hu, sp. nov. and Tenthredo triangulimacula Wei et Hu, sp. nov. The
   former belongs to Tenthredo trunca group and the latter belongs to
   Tenthredo triangulifera group. The diagnosis and the species
   distribution of the Tenthredo trunca group and T. triangulifera group
   are briefly discussed. A key to species of T. triangulifera group is
   provided. The type specimens are deposited in the Insect Collection of
   Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan,
   China.
C1 Wei, Mei-Cai; Cent South Univ Forestry & Technol, Lab Insect Systemat &
   Evolutionary Biol, Changsha, Hunan, 410000, China, China.
EM hupingcs@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739

   length 1.1 mm. Compound eyes bare, cibarium with 8 fine teeth, AR 1.99.

   Hypopygium. Holotype female, paratype I male, 1 June 2004, Liuba
   (33.6[degree]N, 106.9[degree]E), Shanxi Province. Etymology. The
   specific name as derived from Liba, type locality of the new species.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF SPINED LOACH (OSTEICHTHYES, COBITIDAE) FROM THE PEARL
   RIVER, GUANGXI OF CHINA.
AU Chen, Yong-Xia (chenyongxia@hbu.edu.cn) 
   Chen, Yi-Feng
   He, De-Kui
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 377-387
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of spined loach, Cobitis australis sp. nov. is described
   from the Yujiang River and the Yongjiang River, a tributaries of the
   Pearl River basin, Guangxi, North China. Based on the sequences of
   mitochondrial cytochrome b gene, the interspecies relationships of
   Cobitis and Iksookimia were examined. The molecular study supported the
   species status of C. australis sp. nov. Cobitis australis is
   distinguished from its congeners by following combination: absence of
   the Gambetta's pigmentation pattern; presence of sexual dimorph colour
   pattern with 17-20 irregular blotches on the dorsum in males and 13 oval
   blotches on the dorsum and the blotches extending tangle-shape on the
   dorsolateral sides in females; 11-13 irregular vertical elongated
   "v"-shape blotches along midlateral lines, and between them more then 20
   vertical bars in males and less than 20 in females; 4-5 striations on
   the dorsal and caudal fins; one slender and long finger-shaped lamina
   circularis at the base of second ray of the male pectoral fins, the
   second ray is elongated nearly filamentous; scales vertical elongated
   and oval, with a large focal area; mental lobes of lower lip pointed not
   ending in a filiform tip; barbels short, barbel length equal to or
   shorter than eye diameter.
C1 Chen, Yong-Xia; Hebei Univ, Coll Life Sci, Baoding, 071002, China,
   China.
EM chenyongxia@hbu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739

   Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS PARAMESOTRITON (CAUDATA, SALAMANDRIDAE).
AU Wang, Chao
   Tian, Ying-Zhou
   Gu, Xiao-Ming (gxmswx@163.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 388-397
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paramesotriton caudopunctatus populations distributed the Wuling
   Mountains were named a new species, Paramesotriton wulingensis, based on
   morphological differences, nuclear POMC and mitochondrial sequence
   molecular data, distinguished the Leishan population of P caudopunctatus
   (topotype) by the following characters: 1) body color is deeper,
   appearing as dark brown, tubercules of the body back are bigger,
   apophysis of dorsal ridges is lower for the new species, body color is
   lighter, brownish yellow, tubercules of the body back are smaller,
   apophysis of dorsal ridges is higher for the Leishan topotype of P.
   caudopunctatus; 2) the suture m the middle of nose protrusion is deeper
   for the new species (versus shallower in the Leishan topotype of P.
   caudopunctatus); 3) the suture lines connected to the prefrontal with
   the nasal is wavy for the new species (versus left and right sides were
   significantly a "A" in the Leishan topotype of P. caudopunctatus); 4)
   for the new species, the squamosal of forehead-squamosal arc vertical
   reach and the front is crude and the back is fine from dorsal view
   (versus horizontally reach and the thickness of the front and the back
   is the same from dorsal view in the Leishan topotype of P.
   caudopunctatus); 5) the frontal branch of pterygoid are longer and
   arrive at the posterior edge of maxillary for the new species (versus
   shorter and don't arrive at the posterior edge of maxillary in the
   Leishan topotype of P. caudopunctatus).
C1 Gu, Xiao-Ming; Guizhou Normal Univ, Sch Life Sci, 180 N Baoshan Rd,
   Guiyang, 550001, China, China.
EM gxmswx@163.com

   Eurasia; Asia; China

TI THE OCCURRENCE OF THE AUSTRALIAN PSYLLID BLASTOPSYLLA OCCIDENTALIS
   TAYLOR (HEMIPTERA, PSYLLOIDEA) FROM CHINA.
AU Yen, Alan L. (alan.yen@dpi.vic.gov.au) 
   Burckhardt, Daniel
   Cen Yi-Jing
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 38
IS 2
PS 436-439
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The psyllid Blastopsylla occidentalis Taylor is an Australian species
   that has extended its range into North and South America, Africa, Europe
   and Asia. This paper presents records of B. occidentalis in China, along
   with the first record of parasitism of this species outside of
   Australia. This species is dependent upon Eucalyptus species, and its
   ability to utilise over 20 different species may be an important factor
   in its world wide spread. This paper synonymises B. occidentalis with
   Blastopsylla barbara Li.

DT Article
TI Polystomatidae (Monogenea) of southern African Anura: Polystoma
   channingi n.sp. parasitic in two closely related Cacosternum species.
AU du Preez, Louis H. (louis.dupreez@nwu.ac.za) 
SO African Zoology
VL 48
IS 1
PS 64-71
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Polystoma channingi is described as a new species of polystomatid
   flatworm (Monogenea) parasitic in the urinary bladder of Cacosternum
   nanum in the Eastern Cape Province, South Africa. In a locality where C.
   nanum and C. boettgeri occur sympatrically the parasite has been found
   in both species. This finding of a Polystoma sp. in two closely related
   host species questions the strict host-specificity generally ascribed to
   the genus, but supports the hypothesis that host-specificity is
   determined by the oncomiracidium's ability to recognize the tadpole as a
   suitable host. This is the first polystome to be described from the
   genus Cacosternum and the ninth species of Polystoma from South Africa.
   The species is distinguished by its huge haptor and suckers relative to
   the body size. The haptor length/body length ratio of 0.38 is by far the
   largest for the known southern African polystomes. The prevalence of
   infection with P. channingi n.sp. was 25% for C. nanum and 40% for C.
   boettgeri, while the mean intensity of infections in adult frogs was 1.5
   for C. boettgeri and 1.0 for C. nanum.
C1 du Preez, Louis H.; North West Univ, Unit Environm Sci & Management,
   Potchefstroom, ZA-2520, South Africa, South Africa.
EM louis.dupreez@nwu.ac.za
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1562-7020
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Cacosternum boettgeri; Cacosternum nanum [Monogenean parasites /
   Polystoma channingi / New parasite species] [South Africa /  / New
   platyhelminth parasite species]. 
   Polystoma channingi [Amphibian hosts / Cacosternum boettgeri / New
   parasite species] [ / Cacosternum nanum / ] [South Africa /  / New
   species from amphibian host]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates

   Platyhelminthes, Monogenea

   Polystoma channingi (Monogenea): [Sp nov, South Africa, Parasite of
   Cacosternum nanum (Amphibia), p. 66; Parasite].

AN ZOOR14912070213
DT Article
TI Thrips species (Insecta: Thysanoptera) associated to Fabaceae of
   agricultural importance in Cerrado and Amazon-Caatinga ecotone from
   Brazilian Mid-North.
AU Bezerra Lima, Elison Fabricio (elisonfabricio@hotmail.com) 
   Monteiro, Renata Chiarini
   Zucchil, Roberto Antonio
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 13
IS 2
PS 283-289
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 2
U2 21
AB Little is known about the Thysanoptera fauna from Brazilian Mid-North.
   In spite of being,a region with at least three biomes and some ecotones,
   the studies on this insect order in the region are related to
   associations to a few cultivated plant species. On Fabaceae, plant
   family with the second largest number of records of thrips species
   associated in Brazil and huge economic importance for Mid-North, there
   are thrips records only on cowpea (Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp.). Due to
   the lack of knowledge on the Thysanoptera fauna in such a diverse area
   and the importance of crops of this family in the region, this research
   aimed to survey the thrips species associated to Fabaceae of
   agricultural importance in areas of Cerrado and Amazon-Caatinga ecotone
   in Brazilian Mid-North, as well as provide basic biological information
   about damage and hosts. Also, comparison between the Thysanoptera fauna
   of fabaceous crops in the region and the rest of the Country and a key
   to species are presented. Thrips were collected on six fabaceous crops
   in four municipalities in the state of Maranhao and in one municipality
   in the state of Piaui. Eight thrips species were identified: Caliothrips
   phaseoli (Pergande, 1895), Frankliniella brevicaulis Hood, 1937, F.
   gardeniae Moulton, 1948, F. insularis (Franklin, 1908), F. schultzei
   (Trybom, 1910), F. tritici (Fitch, 1855), Haplothrips gowdeyi (Franklin,
   1908) and Salpingothrips minimus Hood, 1935. Two other unidentified
   species were collected: Plesiothrips sp. and Scolothrips sp. Except for
   F. schultzei, the thrips species surveyed in Maranhao are first records
   in the state, and F. gardeniae is first record in the state of Piaui.
   The first records of thrips on Phaseolus lunatus L. in Brazil were
   established. Some species known as pests of Fabaceae mostly in southern
   and southeastern Brazil were not found in Mid-North. Voucher-specimens
   are deposited at the Entomological Collection of the Department of
   Entomology and Acarology, Escola Superior de Agricultura "Luiz de
   Queiroz", Universidade de Sao Paulo (ESALQ/USP).
C1 Bezerra Lima, Elison Fabricio; Univ Sao Paulo, Escola Super Agr Luiz de
   Queiroz, Av Padua Dias 11, Piracicaba, SP, BR-13418900 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM elisonfabricio@hotmail.com
RI Zucchi, Roberto/D-7738-2012; Lima, Elison Fabricio Bezerra/B-7827-2013
OI Zucchi, Roberto/0000-0001-9861-7460; Bezerra Lima, Elison
   Fabricio/0000-0002-6361-0928
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1806-129X; 1676-0611
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts;
   Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Caliothrips phaseoli; Frankliniella brevicaulis; Frankliniella
   insularis; Frankliniella tritici; Haplothrips gowdeyi; Plesiothrips;
   Salpingothrips minimus; Scolothrips [Plant hosts / Fabaceae / New
   record] [Brazil / Maranhao / ]. 
   Frankliniella gardeniae [Plant hosts / Crotalaria / New record] [ /
   Glycine max / ] [Brazil / Piaui / ]. 
   Frankliniella schultzei [Plant hosts / Fabaceae / Records] [Brazil /
   Maranhao / ]. 
   Thysanoptera [Plant hosts / Fabaceae / Key to parasite species] [Brazil
   / Mid-north / Key to species; parasites of Fabaceae (Plant)]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanoptera
OR Thysanoptera (Insecta): [Key to species, Brazil, Mid-north, Parasites of
   Fabaceae (Plant), p. 286; Parasite]. 
   Caliothrips phaseoli (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Frankliniella brevicaulis (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Frankliniella gardeniae (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Frankliniella insularis (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Frankliniella schultzei (Thysanoptera): [Parasite]. 
   Frankliniella tritici (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Haplothrips gowdeyi (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Plesiothrips (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Salpingothrips minimus (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Scolothrips (Thysanoptera): [Parasite; New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of Yanornis (Aves: Ornithurae) from the Lower Cretaceons
   strata of Yixian, Liaoning Province.
AU Wang Xu-ri (wang198109@163.com) 
   Ji Qiang
   Teng Fang-fang
   Jin Ke-mo
SO Dizhi Tongbao
VL 32
IS 4
PS 601-606
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A nearly complete specimen of Yanornis was recently discovered from the
   Early Cretaceous Yixian Formation at Yixian, Jinzhou City, Liaoning
   Province. This specimen shows typical characteristics of Yanornis, such
   as the straight dentary, about 2/3 the length of skull, with about 20
   teeth on each side. The cervicals are long and heterocoelous. The
   synsacrum is composed of 9 sacrals. The length ratio of forelimb to
   hincllimb is about 1.1. The proximal pedal phalanges are longer and more
   robust than the distal ones. However, the new specimen is different born
   the type species- Yanornis martini, by having the following unique
   charactenstics: the humerus has a large and strong deltoid crest, which
   is almost half the length of the shaft. The pubic symphysis is short,
   with the same length as the pygostyle, and is less than 1/6 the length
   of the pubis. 'Elie fibular is long, about 4/5 the length of feniur and
   2/3 the length of the tibiotarsus. The tarsometatarsus is short and
   completely fused, less than Lill the length of the tibiotarsus. This
   specimen can be erected as a new species of Yanornis - Yanornis
   guozhangi sp. nov., on the basis of its unique characteristics and a
   comparison with Yixianornis grabaui, Songlingornis linghensis and
   Yanornis martini. It is notable that three fish fossils were preserved
   along the neck of Yanornis guozhangi sp. nov., which provides important
   informat on for studying the living habit and growth pattern of
   Yanornis.
C1 Wang Xu-ri; Chinese Acad Geol Sci, Inst Geol, Beijing, 100037, China,
   China.
EM wang198109@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1671-2552
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Yanornis guozhangi [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Yanornithiformes
OR Yanornis guozhangi (Yanornithiformes): [Sp nov, Liaoning, Cretaceous, P.
   602; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Black-footed Albatross chicks regurgitated mesopelagic nektons.
AU Oka, Nariko (oka@yamashina.or.jp) 
   Tsuchiya, Koutaro
   Kohno, Hiroshi
   Kikuchi, Tomohiko
   Maruyama, Takashi
SO Japanese Journal of Ornithology
VL 62
IS 1
PS 52-56
PD April 2013
PY 2013
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Food remains incidentally regurgitated by four maturing Black-footed
   Albatross Phoebastria nigripes chicks on Torishima
   (30[degree]29[minute]02[second]N, 140[degree]18[minute]11[second]E), Izu
   Islands in mid-May 2000, were identified. All four chicks regurgitated
   mesopelagic nektons: four squid families consisting of Architeuthidae
   (Architeuthis sp.), Chiroteuthidae (Chiroteuthis sp.), Cranchiidae
   (Megalocranchia sp.) and Sthenoteuthis oualaniensis (Ommastrephidae), as
   well as Chiasmodontidae fish (the first record as prey of Black-footed
   Albatross) and Notostomus japonicus (an Oplophoridae shrimp). Albatross
   parents probably scavenged these prey items from the ocean surface, when
   these mesopelagic organisms (either moribund or dead) surfaced, possibly
   as a result of human activities, foraging activities by marine pursuit
   predators, or for other reasons.
C1 Oka, Nariko; Yamashina Institute for Ornithology, 115 Konoyama, Abiko,
   Chiba 270-1145, Japan, Japan.
EM oka@yamashina.or.jp

AN ZOOR15112081795
DT Article
TI Prevalence and spectrum of helminths in free-ranging African buffaloes
   (Syncerus caffer) in wildlife protected areas, Tanzania.
AU Swai, Emanuel Senyael (ESswai@gmail.com) 
   Mshanga, Deogratius
   Fyumagwa, Robert
   Mpanduji, Deogratius
   Chuma, Idrisa
   Kuya, Sayael
   Eblate, Ernest
   Katale, Zablon
   Keyyu, Julius
SO Journal of Coastal Life Medicine
VL 1
IS 2
PS 145-150
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Objective: To determine the prevalence and spectrum of helminths in
   free-ranging African in Tanzania by a cross-sectional study. Methods:
   Faecal samples (n=123) from Arusha National Park and Ngorongoro Crater
   were examined for helminth eggs using sedimentation and floatation
   techniques during the period of March to June 2012. Results:
   Coprological examination revealed that 34.1%. (n=42) of the buffaloes
   excreted nematodes and trematocies eggs and protozoan oocyst in their
   faces. The pattern of infection was either single or mixed. Single
   (52.4%1 and concurrent infections with two, three, four and five
   parasites were recorded in 19.0%, 14.3% and 2.3% respectively, of the
   cases. The nematode eggs encountered were those of Trichostrongylus sp.
   (20.3%), Oesophagosiomum sp. (7.3%) Strongyle sp. (4.1%) Bunostomum sp.
   (4.1%), Ostertegia sp. (3.3%) and Toxocara sp. (2.4%). The trematode
   eggs encountered were those of Fasciola sp. (9.8%), Paramphistomum
   sp.(4.9%), Gastrothylax sp. Ornithobilharzia sp. (0.81%) and
   Fischoederius sp (0.81%). The protozoan oocyst recorded was that of
   Eimeria sp. (8.1%). Geographical location of buffaloes had significant
   influence on the prevalence of infection with Trichostrongylus (P=0.046)
   and Fasciola (P=0.001)., and the mean prevalances in Anisha National
   Park are significantly higher than those in Ngorongoro Crater. Age had
   significant influence on infection with Fasciola (P=0.036), and juvenile
   recorded higher levels of infection than sub-adults. Health status. body
   condition score and sex-wise prevalence of helminths were not
   significant (P>0.05). Conclusions: This study indicates that helininths
   species are numerous and highly prevalent in the two protected areas and
   may be one of the contributing factors to lower buffalo productivity.
C1 Swai, Emanuel Senyael; VIC, Box 1068, Arusha, Tanzania, Tanzania.
EM ESswai@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 2309-5288; 2309-6152
BD Biometrics; Reproduction; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Nematoda; Protozoa; Trematoda [Mammalian hosts / Syncerus caffer /
   Prevalence] [Tanzania / Arusha National Park & Ngorongoro Crater / ]. 
   Syncerus caffer [Age /  / platyhelminth parasites; prevalence] [Sex
   differences /  / ] [Parasites / Trematoda (Platyhelminthes) / ]
   [Nematode parasites /  / ] [Protozoan parasites /  / ] [Tanzania /
   Arusha National Park & Ngorongoro Crater / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Platyhelminths;
   Protozoans; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae,
   Platyhelminthes, Protozoa
OR Protozoa: [Parasite]. 
   Nematoda (Animalia): [Parasite]. 
   Syncerus caffer (Bovidae): [Host]. 
   Trematoda (Platyhelminthes): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15112081795
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15207045039
PM 23786059
DT Article
TI The Influence of Insecticides and Vegetation in Structuring Formica
   Mound Ant Communities (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in Maine Lowbush
   Blueberry.
AU Choate, Beth (bchoate@allegheny.edu) 
   Drummond, Francis A.
SO Journal of Economic Entomology
VL 106
IS 2
PS 716-726
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 25
AB Assessing the influence of new, reduced-risk insecticides on natural
   enemies within agroecosystems is essential to developing integrated pest
   management strategies. Three species of mound-building Formica ants are
   abundant throughout Maine lowbush blueberry fields (Formica exsectoides
   Forel, F. glacialis Wheeler, and F. ulkei Emery). All three species have
   been described in the literature as predaceous, with research
   demonstrating that F. exsectoides preys on major pest insects of lowbush
   blueberry. The objectives of this study were to determine the impact of
   common-use and newly introduced insecticides on Formica sp. ant
   communities in lowbush blueberry fields. Laboratory assays indicated
   that the commonly applied insecticide phosmet is toxic to F.
   exsectoides, even after 8 d of field weathering (P < 0.05). Species
   comparisons indicated that susceptibility varied with exposure to
   residues in the field. However, some of the reduced-risk biorational
   insecticides, such as acetamiprid, had little effect on survival of all
   three species. Abundance of each species in the field varied with
   lowbush blueberry pesticide-use strategy and amount of nonblueberry
   vegetation. Both F. exsectoides and F. glacialis were most abundant in
   organic fields; however, overall F. glacialis was the most abundant in
   fields of all management types. Field surveys support laboratory results
   suggesting that phosmet is highly toxic to these species and influences
   their spatial pattern. Manipulation of the crop to conserve natural
   enemies in lowbush blueberry is difficult because the crop is not
   planted; therefore, we must look closely at the incorporation of low
   toxicity insecticides with natural enemies to efficiently control pest
   insects.
C1 Choate, Beth; Allegheny Coll, Dept Environm Sci, 520 N Main St,
   Meadville, PA, 16335, USA, USA.
EM bchoate@allegheny.edu
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Nutrition &Dietetics

PM 23786080
DT Article
TI Predictive Modelling of Adult Emergence in a Polyphagous Eucolaspis
   (Chrysomelidae: Eumolpinae) Leaf Beetle.
AU Doddala, P.R.C. (p.r.c.doddala@massey.ac.nz) 
   Trewick, S.A.
   Rogers, D.J.
   Minor, M.A.
SO Journal of Economic Entomology
VL 106
IS 2
PS 899-904
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 11
AB Eucolaspis sp. "Hawke's Bay" (Chrysomelidae: Eumolpinae) is a pest that
   inflicts huge economic loss in many organic apple (Malus domestica
   Borkh.) orchards in New Zealand. The timing of control methods for this
   pest has been shown to be crucial for success. To aid in planning
   control programs, we studied threshold temperature and degree-days
   required for the development of Eucolaspis sp. "Hawke's Bay" pupae and
   modeled adult emergence in the field. Pupal development was observed at
   three constant temperatures. Pupae required 237.0 [plus or minus] 21.67
   degree-days above lower threshold temperature of 4.7[degree]C [plus or
   minus] 0.89[degree]C to develop into adults. The emergence of adults was
   modeled with these thermal values and the model was tested for accuracy
   with field data. The model performed well with a precision of [plus or
   minus]4 d. The proposed phenology model has wide applicability in
   monitoring and planning pest control measures.
C1 Doddala, P.R.C.; Massey Univ, Inst Nat Resources, Palmerston North,
   4442, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM p.r.c.doddala@massey.ac.nz

PT J
AN ZOOR15008040743
DT Article
TI Decadal variation in the diet of western stock stellar sealions
   (Eumetopias jubatus).
AU Sinclair, E.H.
   Johnson, D.S.
   Zeppelin, T.K.
   Gelati, T.S.
SO NOAA Technical Memorandum NMFS-AFSC
VL 248
PS i-viii, 1-67
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Steller sea lions (Eumetopias jubatus) are listed as an endangered
   species in western Alaska due to a precipitous decline that occurred in
   the 1980s and 1990s. In 2000, cascading declines slowed or ceased and
   clusters of rookeries between the eastern Aleutian Islands and eastern
   Gulf of Alaska began to show signs of population growth. Reasons for the
   decline and for a range-wide failure to recover are unresolved, but
   reduction in the availability of prey due to commercial fishing or
   environmental perturbation has been hypothesized. Discerning the diet
   and patterns of prey use by Steller sea lions (SSL) is fundamental to
   isolating the mechanisms driving population health. Here we evaluate the
   frequency of occurrence (FO) of prey species in 3,412 scats of adult
   female and juvenile SSL collected during 1999-2009, across the range of
   the U. S. Western Stock. Thirteen primary prey are identified based on
   their occurrence in > 5% of total scats. We reduce the dimension of the
   diet profile of the 13 primary prey to two categorical groups through
   principal component analysis (PC). A hierarchical cluster analysis of PC
   scores on collection site locations describes four geographic regions of
   SSL diet (with Amak Island as an outlier) nearly identical to those
   identified in a previously published 1990-1998 (n = 3,762) dataset.
   Geographic regions of diet continue to correspond with regional
   population trends of SSL. The species of primary prey consumed by SSL
   are analogous between 1990-1998 and 1999-2009. However, the rangewide FO
   of 7 of the 13 primary prey increased significantly (p < 0.05) during
   the latter decade. Only cephalopods (Gonatidae) and walleye pollock
   (Theragra chalcogramma) decreased significantly in FO in any season or
   region between decades. Generalized linear mixed models (GLMM) of
   seasonal prey FO determined that trends in the FO of primary prey
   between decades were locally driven by significant changes within one or
   more of the four diet regions and fishery conservation management areas
   (RCA). The most significant increases (p = 0.001) in FO during 1999-2009
   were for commercial fishes: arrowtooth flounder (Atheresthes sp.), Atka
   mackerel (Pleurogrammus monoptelygius), rock sole (Lepidopsetta sp.),
   and Pacific cod (Gadus macrocephalus); and one non-commercial fish
   species (Pacific sand lance, Ammodytes hexapterus) in diet Regions 2 and
   3 (RCA zones 6 and 7) between the eastern Aleutian Islands and western
   Gulf of Alaska. Diversity scores (H') for primary prey were also highest
   in these regions compared to the previous decade, and are coincident
   with SSL population increases that began in the same area in 2000. Atka
   mackerel continues to dominate SSL diet west of Samalga Pass, and
   walleye pollock continues to dominate SSL diet east of Samalga Pass
   (despite its decreased presence in diets in Regions 1-3 during
   1999-2009). The results of generalized additive mixed models (GAMM) of
   annual trends (1990-2009) in summer prey FO on each rookery across the
   study area are consistent with the results of GLMM decadal comparisons.
   The additional 11 years of data presented here support earlier
   conclusions that adult female and young juvenile SSL of the Western
   Stock collectively eat a wide variety of prey species, but demonstrate
   fidelity to prey types that are predictably available in seasonal
   concentrations over the continental shelf or other bathymetric
   structures, within close range of natal rookery sites. Foraging within
   close proximity to birth and breeding sites keeps adult females close to
   pups onshore and to young juveniles learning to forage. However, it also
   increases their vulnerability to potential nearshore environmental and
   anthropogenic interference which could ultimately influence their
   reproductive success. It was not the objective of this study to define
   the relationship between SSL diet and population decline, or to identify
   the interactive mechanisms that drive diet change. However, coincident
   patterns emerged that suggest relationships between SSL diet, regional
   population patterns, climate and fisheries. Some of the patterns are
   worthy of discussion and future research: 1) the areas of greatest
   increases in the FO and diversity of prey (Regions 2 and 3) beginning in
   1999, overlap with those of the strongest population growth since 1999;
   2) the increase in primary prey FO and diversity since 1999 is
   coincident with increased restrictions on groundfish trawling within SSL
   Critical Habitat, enacted in 2000; and 3) the area of lowest prey
   diversity (Region 4) overlaps with those areas of continuing population
   declines, the most restricted foraging habitat (narrow continental
   shelf) and the lowest seasonal and temporal variability in sea surface
   temperature in all years of study.
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BD Nutrition; Feeding behaviour; Ecology; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Eumetopias jubatus [Diet /  / Decadal variation] [Food availability /
   Prey availability / ] [Food preferences /  / ] [Population dynamics /
   Population decline / ] [North Pacific / USA, Alaska, Gulf of Alaska / ].
   
TN Carnivores; Chordates; Mammals; Pinnipeds; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Carnivora, Otariidae
OR Eumetopias jubatus (Otariidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15008040743
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15001000217
DT Article
TI An Abelisauroid Theropod Dinosaur from the Turonian of Madagascar.
AU Farke, Andrew A. (afarke@webb.org) 
   Sertich, Joseph J.W.
SO PLoS ONE
VL 8
IS 4
PS e62047, 1-18
PD Apr 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Geophysical evidence strongly supports the complete isolation of India
   and Madagascar (Indo-Madagascar) by [approximately]100 million years
   ago, though sparse terrestrial fossil records from these regions prior
   to [approximately]70 million years ago have limited insights into their
   biogeographic history during the Cretaceous. A new theropod dinosaur,
   Dahalokely tokana, from Turonian-aged ([approximately]90 million years
   old) strata of northernmost Madagascar is represented by a partial axial
   column. Autapomorphies include a prominently convex prezygoepipophyseal
   lamina on cervical vertebrae and a divided infraprezygapophyseal fossa
   through the mid-dorsal region, among others. Phylogenetic analysis
   definitively recovers the species as an abelisauroid theropod and weakly
   as a noasaurid. Dahalokely is the only known dinosaur from the interval
   during which Indo-Madagascar likely existed as a distinct landmass, but
   more complete material is needed to evaluate whether or not it is more
   closely related to later abelisauroids of Indo-Madagascar or those known
   elsewhere in Gondwana.
C1 Farke, Andrew A.; Raymond M Alf Museum Paleontol, Claremont, CA, USA,
   USA.
EM afarke@webb.org
SC Zoology
SN 1932-6203
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Abelisauroidea [Madagascar /  / new record] [Cretaceous / Turonian / ]. 
   Dahalokely [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Dahalokely tokana [Madagascar /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Abelisauroidea (Theropoda): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Dahalokely (Theropoda): [Gen nov, Of Abelisauroidea, Type species
   Dahalokely tokana, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Dahalokely tokana (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Madagascar, Cretaceous, P. 3;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15001000217
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15001000252
DT Article
TI One Extinct Turtle Species Less: Pelusios seychellensis Is Not Extinct,
   It Never Existed.
AU Stuckas, Heiko
   Gemel, Richard
   Fritz, Uwe (uwe.fritz@senckenberg.de) 
SO PLoS ONE
VL 8
IS 4
PS e57116, 1-7
PD Apr 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pelusios seychellensis is thought to be a freshwater turtle species
   endemic to the island of Mahe, Seychelles. There are only three museum
   specimens from the late 19th century known. The species has been never
   found again, despite intensive searches on Mahe . Therefore, P.
   seychellensis has been declared as "Extinct" by the IUCN and is the sole
   putatively extinct freshwater turtle species. Using DNA sequences of
   three mitochondrial genes of the historical type specimen and
   phylogenetic analyses including all other species of the genus, we
   provide evidence that the description of P. seychellensis was
   erroneously based on a widely distributed West African species, P.
   castaneus. Consequently, we synonymize the two species and delete P.
   seychellensis from the list of extinct chelonian species and from the
   faunal list of the Seychelles.
C1 Fritz, Uwe; Senckenberg Dresden, Museum Zool, Dresden, Germany, Germany.
EM uwe.fritz@senckenberg.de
SC Zoology
SN 1932-6203
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Land zones; Oceanic islands; Indian
   Ocean islands
DE Pelusios seychellensis [Seychelles /  / Deletion from list of extinct
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Pleurodira, Pelomedusidae
OR Pelusios castaneus (Pelomedusidae): [Syn nov, Pelusios seychellensis
   (Siebenrock 1906), p. 6]. 
   Pelusios seychellensis (Pelomedusidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15001000252
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Description of a new genus and a new species of Machilidae (Insecta:
   Microcoryphia) from Turkey.
AU Bach de Roca, Carmen (Carmen.Bach@uab.cat) 
   Fanciulli, Pietro-Paolo
   Cicconardi, Francesco
   Molero-Baltanas, Rafael
   Gaju-Ricart, Miguel
SO Soil Organisms
VL 85
IS 1
PS 31-39
PD April 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species and a new genus of Microcoryphia from Turkey are
   described. The new genus, named Turquimachilis has, as its most
   important distinctive feature, the presence in the male of unique
   parameres on the IXth urostemite, with proximal protuberances and
   chaetotaxy. They are different from all the other genera of the order.
   This alone is sufficient to allow the creation of a new genus. We add
   other anatomical characteristics that allow us to differentiate the new
   genus from the closest known genera. The type species is described.
C1 Bach de Roca, Carmen; Autonomous Univ Barcelona, Dept Anim & Vegetal
   Biol & Ecol, Bellaterra, Barcelona, 08193, Spain, Spain.
EM Carmen.Bach@uab.cat
OI Cicconardi, Francesco/0000-0001-6509-6179

   Eurasia

   Turquimachilis mendesi, p. 32]. 
   Turquimachilis mendesi (Thysanura): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 32].

PT J
AN ZOOR15210063011
DT Article
TI First record of the humback whale (Megaptera novaeangliae) as
   opportunistic feed off the coast of Oaxaca, Mexico.
FT Primer registro de alimentacion oportunista de ballena jorobada
   (Megaptera novaeangliae) en la costa de Oaxaca, Mexico.
AU Villegas-Zurita, Francisco (fvillegas@angel.umar.mx) 
   Castillejos-Moguel, Fatima
SO THERYA
VL 4
IS 1
PS 113-119
PD Apr 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB We report the first record of opportunistic feeding behavior of one
   humpback whale during its winter migration through tropical waters off
   the central coast of Oaxaca, Mexico. Additionally, we recorded for the
   first time evidence of mixed feeding techniques, mainly consisting of
   lunging vertically, which is used in feeding grounds of the North
   Pacific and skimming lunge subsurface, which is used in feeding grounds
   of the South Pacific, with the latter one being specifically used for
   catching Munida sp. aggregations. The method described adds four new
   variants to the maneuver repertoire: 1) buzz prior to the prey capture,
   2) type of targeted prey, Cupleiformes in this case, 3) emergence with
   the mouth closed, and 4) movement in the surface with the mouth closed.
   Based on the characteristics of this method we named it subsurface lunge
   feeding with terminal buzz. This is the southernmost feeding record that
   has been reported for the North Pacific humpback whales.
C1 Villegas-Zurita, Francisco; Univ del Mar, Inst Ecol, Ciudad Univ S-N,
   Puerto Angel Oaxaca, 70902, Mexico, Mexico.
EM fvillegas@angel.umar.mx
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 2007-3364
BD Techniques; Nutrition; Diet; Feeding behaviour; Foraging; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Megaptera novaeangliae [Feeding analysis techniques / Mixed feeding
   techniques / first record] [Prey /  / ] [Feeding behaviour /
   Opportunistic feeding behaviour / ] [Foraging / Feeding grounds / ]
   [Food capture /  / ] [North Pacific / Mexico, Oaxaca / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Cetacea, Balaenopteridae
OR Megaptera novaeangliae (Balaenopteridae): [Predator; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15210063011
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

   for the first time. Variation in the color pattern of the females is

   Levi, 2007 and M. pia Chamberlin & Ivie, 1936 are presented.

DT Article
TI Comments on the genus Neoclides UVAROV, 1940 with the description of a
   new species (Phasmatodea: Diapheromerinae: Necrosciinae).
AU Bresseel, Joachim (joachimbresseel@gmail.com) 
SO Polish Journal of Entomology
VL 82
IS 1
PS 3-11
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Neoclides UVAROV, 1940; Neoclides heitzmanni sp. n. is
   described and illustrated from the adult female and egg. It is the first
   time that an egg of the genus is described and illustrated. Lectotypes
   are designated for Neoclides simyra (WESTWOOD, 1859), and Neoclides
   rivalis (REDTENBACHER, 1908) stat. rev. comb. n., which is hereby
   removed from the synonymy with Neoclides simyra (WESTWOOD, 1859). Both
   lectotypes are illustrated. The distribution range of the genus is
   extended to southern Vietnam. The record of Neoclides magistralis from
   Peninsular Malaysia is clearly an error and represents an undescribed
   species.
C1 Bresseel, Joachim; Royal Belgian Inst Nat Sci, Vautier St 29, Brussels,
   B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM joachimbresseel@gmail.com
SC Zoology

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

   Neocles rivalis - Redtenbacher 1908 (Phasmida): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 4; Referred to, Neoclides, p. 4].

   Transferred from Neocles, p. 4; Removal from synonymy, With Neoclides

DT Article
TI Eutarsopolipus americanus sp noy. (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Chlaenius praesinus Dejean (Coleoptera: Carabidae) from
   Michigan and Missouri, USA.
AU Husband, Robert W. (husbandadrian@aol.com) 
   Husband, David O.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 53-60
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Eutarsopolipus americanus sp. nov. (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral,
   haemolymph-feeding parasite of Chlaenius praesinus Dejean 1826
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae), is described from Oceana County, Michigan and
   Adair and St. Louis Counties, Missouri. Relationships with 17 previously
   described species in the myzus group of Eutarsopolipus are discussed.
   Species in the myzus group parasitize beetle species of the genera
   Chlaenius, Poecilus, Scarites and Diplocheila. Eutarsopolipus americanus
   is the first species in the Western Hemisphere in the myzus group with
   adult females with stylets exceeding 80 micrometers.
C1 Husband, Robert W.; Adrian Coll, Dept Biol, Adrian, MI, 49221, USA, USA.
EM husbandadrian@aol.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1362-1971
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Chlaenius praesinus [Arachnid parasites / Eutarsopolipus americanus /
   New parasite species] [Michigan /  / New arachnid parasite species]. 
   Eutarsopolipus americanus [Coleopteran hosts / Chlaenius praesinus / New
   parasite species] [Michigan /  / New species from coleopteran host]
   [Missouri /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Beetles; Chelicerates; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga,
   Caraboidea, Carabidae

   Chlaenius praesinus (Coleoptera), p. 53; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Eutarsopolipus asiaticus sp nov (Aeari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Chlaenius costiger Chaudoir (Coleoptera: Carabidae) from
   Japan.
AU Husband, Robert W. (husbandadrian@aol.com) 
   Kurosa, Kazuyoshi
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 61-70
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eutarsopolipus asiaticus sp. nov. (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Chlaenius costiger Chaudoir (Coleoptera: Carabidae), is
   described from Japan. Relationships with 18 previously described species
   in the myzus group of Eutarsopolipus are discussed and keys are provided
   to species in the myzus group. This is the first record of
   Eutarsopolipus in the myzus group in Japan and represents a subgroup of
   species in the myzus group with cheliceral stylets 90 micrometers or
   longer.

DT Article
TI Two new species of oribatid mites of the superfamily Oripodoidea (Acari:
   Oribatida) from Ethiopia.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Rybalov, Leonid B.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 71-79
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the superfamily Oripodoidea, Scheloribates
   (Bischeloribates) lizelhugoae sp. nov. and Zygoribatula josefstaryi sp.
   nov. are described from material collected from an expedition to
   Ethiopia during February and March 2012. An annotated checklist of
   identified oribatid mite taxa is presented. Seven species and two genera
   are the first records for Ethiopia.

   Novgorod Referral Ctr, Nizhniy Novgorod, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Oribatid mites (Acari: Oribatida) from acacia and pine plantations in
   southern Vietnam, with description of a new species of the subgenus
   Galumna (Cosmogalumna).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, Alexander E.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 80-88
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB An annotated checklist of oribatid mite taxa from acacia and pine
   plantations of Dong Nai Culture and Nature Reserve (Southern Vietnam) is
   presented. The species Ctenacarus araneola, Nehypochthonius porosus,
   Scheloribates mahunkai, Scheloribates kraepelini, Indoribates
   panabokkei, genera Ctenacarus, Nehypochthonius and families Ctenacaridae
   and Nehypochthoniidae are first records from Vietnam, and of these
   Nehypochthoniidae, Nehypochthonius and Nehypochthonius porosus are first
   records from the Oriental region. A new oribatid mite species, Galumna
   (Cosmogalumna) dongnaiensis sp. nov. (Galumnidae), is described from
   soil in a pine plantation. The new species is distinguishable from all
   species of the subgenus Galumna (Cosmogalumna) by the sculpturing of the
   prodorsum and pteromorphs and the number of notogastral porose areas.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanitary Inspect, Nizhniy
   Novgorod Referral Ctr, Nizhniy Novgorod, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru

   Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   Oribatida [Checklists / Annotated & distributional checklists / ]
   [Cultivated land habitat / Acacia & pine plantation / ] [Vietnam / Dong
   Nai Province / ].

   Oribatida (Acari).

PM 23261086
DT Article
TI Genetic characterization of the blood-sucking nematodes Libyostrongylus
   dentatus and Libyostrongylus douglassii supports their different
   evolutionary history.
AU Andrade, Josiana G.
   Iniguez, Alena M. (alena@ioc.fiocruz.br) 
   Souza, Adriane N.
   Marques, Valeria C.L.
   de Souza Filho, Goncalo A.
   Santos, Clovis P.
   DaMatta, Renato A.
SO Veterinary Parasitology
VL 193
IS 1-3
PS 193-199
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Libyostrongylus sp. are nematodes that infect ostriches. Libyostrongylus
   douglassii was first described in ostriches from several countries in
   the world. Later Libyostrongylus dentatus was morphologically identified
   in ostriches in the USA and Brazil, and mixed infection is common in the
   latter country. The internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of the
   ribosomal DNA gene is used for genetic variability assessment and
   phylogenetic reconstruction for many organisms. Through genetic analysis
   the status of different species morphologically defined was confirmed
   and a molecular method was developed to differentiate both species.
   ITS1, 5.8S, ITS2 regions of L. douglassii and L dentatus were
   characterized. Regarding complete ITS region, the K2-p genetic distance
   between the species was 0.060 (SE 0.008) and the intra-specific distance
   was 0.002 (SE0.001) for L. dentatus and 0.006 (SE 0.002) for
   L.douglassii. NJ and MP phylogenetic analysis of ITS1 and ITS2 regions
   indicated that both species belong to the Trichostrongylidae family, and
   are evolutionarily different, suported by high bootstrap value. Based on
   ITS DNA polymorphisms, a molecular approach was designed to detect both
   species. These results are the first molecular characterization of L.
   douglassii and L dentatus, and provide new tools for the identification
   of these parasites of veterinary importance. (C) 2012 Elsevier B.V. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Iniguez, Alena M.; Fundacao Oswaldo Cruz, Inst Oswaldo Cruz, Pavilhao
   Rocha Lima,Sala 518,Av Brasil 4365, Rio De Janeiro, RJ, BR-21045900 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM alena@ioc.fiocruz.br
RI DaMatta, Renato/G-8367-2015; de Paula Santos, Clovis/F-8434-2012; de
   Souza Filho, Goncalo/S-7251-2017
OI DaMatta, Renato/0000-0002-0108-9268; de Paula Santos,
   Clovis/0000-0003-1416-288X; de Souza Filho, Goncalo/0000-0003-1028-4425;
   INIGUEZ, ALENA/0000-0002-9788-9533
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Parasitology
SN 0304-4017
BD Systematics; Genetics; Evolution; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts
DE Libyostrongylus dentatus; Libyostrongylus douglassii [Molecular genetics
   / ITS DNA polymorphisms / taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Molecular
   phylogeny / ] [Variation /  / ] [Avian hosts / Struthio camelus / ]. 
   Struthio camelus [Nematode parasites / Libyostrongylus dentatus /
   Molecular phylogeny & systematics] [ / Libyostrongylus douglassii / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Vertebrates

   Nematoda
OR Struthio camelus (Struthionidae): [Host]. 
   Libyostrongylus dentatus (Nematoda): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI Kokuraichthys tokuriki n. gen. and sp., Early Cretaceous
   osteoglossomorph fish in Kyushu, Japan.
AU Yabumoto, Yoshitaka (yabumoto@kmnh.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the Kitakyushu Museum of Natural History and Human History
   Series A Natural History
VL 11
PS 67-72
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Kokuraichthys tokuriki is described from the Early Cretaceous Dobaru
   Formation of the Wakino Subgroup, Kitakyushu in the northern part of
   Kyushu, Japan, as a new genus.and species of Osteoglossomorpha. This new
   species is considered to be more closely related to Hiodontiformes or
   Lycopteriformes than Osteoglossiformes because it has a single epural
   and no neural spine on the first ural centrum. Although it has
   significantly fewer vertebrae (36 or 37), K tokuriki is tentatively
   assigned to Hiodontiformes because of the long anal fin base, the
   anterior position of the dorsal fin and the reduced neural spine on the
   first preural centrum.
C1 Yabumoto, Yoshitaka; Kitakyushu Museum Nat Hist & Human Hist,
   Yahatahigashi Ku, 2-4-1 Higashida, Kitakyushu, Fukuoka, 8050071, Japan,
   Japan.
EM yabumoto@kmnh.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1348-2653

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Kokuraichthys tokuriki [Japan /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

TI Four new species of the genus Oxycentrus from Asia (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae: Harpalini).
AU Ito, Noboru (noboru.itou23@konicaminolta.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the Osaka Museum of Natural History
VL 67
PS 1-9
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the genus Oxycentrus are described as Oxycentrus
   (Oxycentrus) scabericollis from Buthan, O. (O.) laetus from Laos, O.
   (O.) sukiclypeus from Myanmar, and O. (O.) angustipennis from Cambodia.
   These species are peculiar in having longitudinal coarse punctate areas
   a little apart from lateral furrows and can be estimated to be clustered
   one species group, but the taxonomic treatment needs examination and
   analysis of all species.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Hippolytid Shrimp Genus Lebbeus (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Caridea) from Lower Bathyal Zone in the Izu Islands, Central
   Japan.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
SO Natural History Research
VL 12
IS 2
PS 81-89
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the hippolytid shrimp genus Lebbeus White, 1847, L.
   lamina, is described and illustrated on the basis of a heterosexual pair
   of specimens from off Miyake Island, Izu Islands, central Japan, at
   depths of 1988-2007 m. It is referred to the species group characterized
   by the possession of epipods on the third maxilliped to third pereopods,
   and appears closest to L. antarcticus (Hale, 1941), L. cristatus Ahyong,
   2010, L. tosaensis Hanamura and Abe, 2003, and L. virentova Nye, Copley,
   Plouviez and Van Dover, 2012. Differentiating characters between the new
   species and its four closest relatives are discussed. Thirteen species
   of Lebbeus are now known from the lower bathyal zone, greater than 1500
   m, though the new species is the first representative from Japanese
   waters occurring at such depths.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Nat Hist Museum & Inst, Chuo Ku, Chiba 955-2 Aoba Cho,
   Chiba, 2608682, Japan, Japan.
EM komai@chiba-muse.or.jp
SC Zoology
SN 0915-9444
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Lebbeus lamina [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Lebbeus lamina (Natantia): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 81].

DT Article
TI Records of Four Species of the Pylochelid Hermit Crab Genus Trizocheles
   Forest, 1987 (Crustacea: Decapoda: Anomura) from the Sagami Sea and Izu
   Islands, Central Japan, with Descriptions of Three New Species.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
SO Natural History Research
VL 12
IS 2
PS 91-112
PD Mar 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study reports on the "symmetrical" hermit crab genus
   Trizocheles Forest, 1987 (Paguroidea: Pylochelidae) collected in the
   Sagami Sea and Izu Islands, central Japan, during a continuous marine
   faunal survey of the Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba. Four
   species were identified, of which three are new to science: T albatrossi
   Forest, 1987, T albipes sp. nov., T inermis sp. nov., and T parvispina
   sp. nov. The three new species are fully described and illustrated, and
   their affinities are discussed. Previous Japanese records referred to T
   spinosus (Henderson, 1888) are not that taxon and have been found to
   actually represent three other species, T albatrossi, T sakaii Forest,
   1987, and Pomatocheles jeffreisii (Miers, 1879). The present findings
   increase the number of species of Trizocheles known from Japanese waters
   to six and the number of species known from the world to w21. An
   identification key to the six Japanese species is provided.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Nat Hist Museum & Inst, Chuo Ku, Chiba 955-2 Aoba Cho,
   Chiba, 2608682, Japan, Japan.
EM komai@chiba-muse.or.jp

PT J
AN ZOOR14911053583
PM 23485974
DT Article
TI Tubicolous enteropneusts from the Cambrian period.
AU Caron, Jean-Bernard (jcaron@rom.on.ca) 
   Conway Morris, Simon
   Cameron, Christopher B.
SO Nature (London)
VL 495
IS 7442
PS 503-506
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 58
AB Hemichordates are a marine group that, apart from one mono-specific
   pelagic larval form, are represented by the vermiform enteropneusts and
   minute colonial tube-dwelling pterobranchs. Together with echinoderms,
   they comprise the clade Ambulacraria1. Despite their restricted
   diversity, hemichordates provide important insights into early
   deuterostome evolution, notably because of their pharyngeal gill slits2.
   Hemichordate phylogeny has long remained problematic3,4, not least
   because the nature of any transitional form that might serve to link the
   anatomically disparate enteropneusts and pterobranchs is conjectural.
   Hence, inter-relationships have also remained controversial. For
   example, pterobranchs have sometimes been compared to ancestral
   echinoderms1. Molecular data identify enteropneusts as paraphyletic, and
   harrimaniids5-8 as the sister group of pterobranchs. Recent molecular
   phylogenies suggest that enteropneusts are probably basal within
   hemichordates, contrary to previous views9, but otherwise provide little
   guidance as to the nature of the primitive hemichordate7,8. In addition,
   the hemichordate fossil record is almost entirely restricted to
   peridermal skeletons of pterobranchs, notably graptolites10,11. Owing to
   their low preservational potentials, fossil enteropneusts are
   exceedingly rare12-15, and throw no light on either hemichordate
   phylogeny or the proposed harrimaniid-pterobranch transition. Here we
   describe an enteropneust, Spartobranchus tenuis (Walcott, 1911), from
   the Middle Cambrian-period (Series 3, Stage 5) Burgess Shale. It is
   remarkably similar to the extant harrimaniids, but differs from all
   known enteropneusts in that it is associated with a fibrous tube that is
   sometimes branched. Wesuggest that this is the precursor of the
   pterobranch periderm, and supports the hypothesis that pterobranchs are
   miniaturized and derived from an enteropneust-like worm5,6. It also
   shows that the periderm was acquired before size reduction and
   acquisition of feeding tentacles, and that coloniality emerged through
   aggregation of individuals, perhaps similar to the Cambrian
   rhabdopleurid Fasciculitubus11. The presence of both suggests that
   hemichordates originated at the onset of the Cambrian explosion.
C1 Caron, Jean-Bernard; Royal Ontario Museum, Dept Nat Hist Palaeobiol,
   Toronto, ON, M5S 2C6, Canada, Canada.
EM jcaron@rom.on.ca
OI Caron, Jean-Bernard/0000-0002-1670-5502
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0028-0836
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Evolution; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Hemichordata [Origin of taxon /  / Significance of enteropneust from
   Cambrian]. 
   Spartobranchus [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
TN Hemichordates; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI A taxonomic revision of the Meranoplus F. Smith of Madagascar
   (Hymenoptera: Formicidae: Myrmicinae) with keys to species and diagnosis
   of the males.
AU Boudinot, Brendon E. (boudinotb@gmail.com) 
   Fisher, Brian L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3635
IS 4
PS 301-339
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The species-level taxonomy of the ant genus Meranoplus F. Smith from
   Madagascar is revised. Two new species, M. cryptomys sp. n. and
   sylvarius sp. n. are described from workers and queens; M. mayri Forel,
   1910, and M. radamae Forel, 1891, are redescribed, and queens and males
   for these two species are described for the first time. The first
   diagnosis of Meranoplus males for any biogeographic region is provided
   based on Malagasy species. Illustrated keys to all known Malagasy castes
   and species are presented. Diagnoses are given for two species groups:
   the M. mayri group and the M. nanus group. The diagnosis of the M. nanus
   species group from Bolton (1981) is thereby expanded with six new
   characters. Two species are known from the M. mayri species group and
   seven described species are known for the M. nanus species group,
   including the two new species described herein. The mouthparts,
   genitalia, and all castes, where known, of Malagasy Meranoplus are
   illustrated.
C1 Boudinot, Brendon E.; 55 Mus Concourse Dr, San Francisco, CA, 94118,
   USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Diversity within the Redeye Bass, Micropterus coosae (Perciformes:
   Centrarchidae) species group, with descriptions of four new species.
AU Baker, Winston H.
   Blanton, Rebecca E. (whlrbaker@earthlink.net) 
   Johnston, Carol E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3635
IS 4
PS 379-401
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB The Redeye Bass, Micropterus coosae, was described from the Mobile River
   basin, Chattahoochee, and Savannah rivers in Alabama and Georgia, USA,
   by Hubbs and Bailey (1940). At that time the authors recognized
   significant variation in the Black Warrior River population, and noted
   that with further study this form may be recognized as a separate taxon.
   An examination of variation in morphology and mitochondrial DNA
   supported this observation, and highlighted additional species-level
   variation, resulting in descriptions of a total of four new species:
   Micropterus cahabae, new sp., restricted to the Cahaba River system;
   Micropterus tallapoosae, new sp., restricted to the Tallapoosa River
   system; Micropterus warriorensis, new sp., from the Black Warrior River
   system; and Micropterus chattahoochae, new sp., from the Chattahoochee
   River system. Micropterus coosae is restricted to the Coosa River
   system. The new species differ from each other and from M. coosae by a
   combination of pigmentation and scale count characteristics, development
   of the tooth patch, and divergence within the ND2 gene. While two of
   these species are relatively common in upland streams within their
   ranges, M. warriorensis, M. cahabae and M. chattahoochae are uncommon
   and may warrant protection.

TI The genus Laccobius in China: new species and new records (Coleoptera:
   Hydrophilidae).
AU Jia, Fenglong
   Gentili, Elio (fenglongjia@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Fikacek, Martin
SO Zootaxa
VL 3635
IS 4
PS 402-418
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The species of the water scavenger beetle genus Laccobius Erichson, 1837
   occuring in China are reviewed. Two new species are described: Laccobius
   (Glyptolaccobius) qinlingensis sp. nov. (Shaanxi) and L.
   (Cyclolaccobius) hainanensis sp. nov. (Hainan). Five species are
   recorded for the first time: Laccobius (Dimorpholaccobius) bipunctatus
   (Fabricius, 1775), L. (D.) striatulus (Fabricius, 1801) and L.
   (Compsolaccobius) pallidissimus Reitter, 1899 (all from Xinjiang), L.
   (Microlaccobius) tonkinensis Gentili, 1979 (Shaanxi), and L.
   (Compsolaccobius) decorus (Gyllenhal, 1827) (Qinghai). Additional
   faunistic data from China are provided for the following species: L.
   (Cyclolaccobius) hingstoni Orchymont, 1926, L. (C.) nitidus Gentili,
   1984, L. (C.) politus Gentili, 1979, L. (C.) yunnanensis Gentili, 2003,
   L. (Dimorpholaccobius) simulans Orchymont, 1923, L. (s. str.) binotatus
   Orchymont, 1934, L. (s. str.) cinereus Motschulsky, 1860, L. (s. str.)
   colon (Stephens, 1829), L. (s. str.) inopinus Gentili, 1980, L. (s.
   str.) minutus (Linnaeus, 1758), L. (s. str.) nobilis Gentili, 1979, L.
   (Microlaccobius) elegans Gentili, 1979, L. (M.) florens Gentili, 1979,
   L. (M.) formosus Gentili, 1979, L. (M.) hammondi Gentili, 1984, L. (M.)
   himalayanus Gentili, 1988, and L. (M.) nepalensis Gentili, 1982. An
   updated checklist of Laccobius species occurring in China is provided.

DT Article
TI Revision of the peristediid genus Satyrichthys (Actinopterygii:
   Teleostei) with the description of a new species, S. milleri sp nov.
AU Kawai, Toshio (kawai@museum.hokudai.ac.jp) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3635
IS 4
PS 419-438
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Indo-Pacific peristediid genus Satyrichthys Kaup, 1873 was first
   diagnosed as having a broad head with mesethmoid, postocular, parietal
   and preopercular spines. Later, most ichthyologists characterized
   Satyrichthys by its toothless jaws and strong preopercular spine. Kawai
   (2008) divided Satyrichthys into two genera, Satyrichthys and Scalicus,
   on the basis of a phylogenetic hypothesis, and redefined Satyrichthys.
   Seven species of Satyrichthys are recognized here, including one new
   species: S. clavilapis, S. laticeps, S. longiceps, S. milleri sp. nov.,
   S. moluccensis, S. rieffeli and S. welchi. The new species is
   distinguished from its congeners in having equilateral-triangular
   rostral projections, 4 lip and 4 chin barbels, and no anterior directed
   spines on the upper lateral row of the caudal peduncle. Satyrichthys
   laticeps, previously treated as a junior synonym of S. moluccensis, is
   regarded as a valid species. The following new synonyms are noted: S.
   adeni, S. halyi and S. magnus are all junior synonyms of S. laticeps; S.
   isokawae is a junior synonym of S. moluccensis; and S. lingi is a junior
   synonym of S. welchi. In addition, a neotype is designated for S.
   moluccensis.
C1 Kawai, Toshio; Hokkaido Univ Museum, Fisheries Sci Ctr, 3-1-1 Minato
   Cho, Hakodate, Hokkaido, 0418611, Japan, Japan.
EM kawai@museum.hokudai.ac.jp

   P. 432]. 
   Satyrichthys - Kaup 1873 (Triglidae): [Revision, P. 420; Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 425; Key to species, P. 420]. 
   Satyrichthys laticeps - (Schlegel 1852) (Triglidae): [Syn nov,
   Satyrichthys adeni (Lloyd 1907), p. 424; Syn nov, Satyrichthys halyi
   (Day 1888), p. 424; Syn nov, Satyrichthys magnus Yatou 1985, p. 424;
   Removal from synonymy, With Satyrichthys moluccensis (Bleeker 1850), p.

TI New species and records of Euphranta Loew and other Adramini (Diptera:
   Tephritidae: Trypetinae) from south and southeast Asia.
AU David, K.J. (davidento@gmail.com) 
   Hancock, D.L.
   Freidberg, A.
   Goodger, K.F.M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3635
IS 4
PS 439-458
PD Mar 28 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Seven new species of Euphranta Loew are described, viz., Euphranta
   dysoxyli David, sp. nov., E. hyalipennis David & Freidberg, sp. nov, E.
   diffusa David, sp. nov., E. haldwanica Hancock & Goodger, sp. nov. and
   E. thandikudi David, sp. nov. from India; E. neochrysopila David,
   Freidberg, Hancock & Goodger, sp. nov. from Sri Lanka and E. ridleyi
   Hancock & Goodger, sp. nov. from Singapore. Notes are provided on the
   identities of E. corticicola (Hering) and E. klugii (Wiedemann); E.
   signatifacies Hardy is synonymised with E. klugii; E. dissoluta (Bezzi)
   and E. burtoni Hardy are synonymised with E. crux (Fabricius) and
   Dimeringophrys parilis (Hardy) is reinstated as a valid species.
   Coelotrypes latilimbatus (Enderlein), Dimeringophrys pallidipennis
   Hardy, D. parilis (Hardy) and Hardyadrama excoecariae Lee are newly
   recorded from India, E. crux from Sri Lanka and E. klugii from
   Indonesia. An unnamed species of Coelopacidia Enderlein from India is
   illustrated. An illustrated key to species of Euphranta Loew from India
   is also provided.
