DT Article
TI Two new species of Trochurinae trilobites from the Middle Devonian
   (Eifelian) of Southern Morocco.
AU Corbacho, Joan (fosilart@hotmail.com) 
   Lopez-Soriano, Francisco J.
SO Batalleria
VL 18
PS 15-24
PD marzo 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of trilobites of the Trochurinae subfamily from the
   Middle Devonian (Eifelian) of the Tafilalt region (Morocco) are
   described. In addition, a new genus (Basseiarges gen. nov.) is proposed
   in order to include one of them (Basseiarges mellishae sp. nov.). The
   main characteristics that make it different from the other members of
   the subfamily Trochurinae are its peculiar cephalon and pygidium, and
   the saw-shape of the ridge that connects the genal spines, which is
   similar to that present on the pygidium border. The second species
   described here is Akantharges mbareki sp. nov. from Tinejad. Both them
   are compared with the previously described species of the genus
   Akantharges. In addition, the first description of the hypostome of a
   member of the genus Akantharges is included.
C1 Corbacho, Joan; Museo Geol Seminario Barcelona, Diputac 231, Barcelona,
   08007, Spain, Spain.
EM fosilart@hotmail.com
RI Lopez-Soriano, Francisco J./W-4947-2018
OI Lopez-Soriano, Francisco J./0000-0003-1493-3023

SN 0214-7831
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Akantharges mbareki; Basseiarges mellishae [Morocco /  / new species]
   [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Basseiarges [Devonian /  / New genus]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Trilobites
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Trilobitomorpha, Trilobita

   Fossil]. 
   Basseiarges (Trilobita): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Trochurinae, Type
   species Basseiarges mellishae, p. 16, Devonian; Fossil]. 
   Basseiarges mellishae (Trilobita): [Sp nov, Morocco, Devonian, P. 17;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new early cheilostome bryozoan from the Aptian (Lower Cretaceous) of
   Valencia, Spain.
AU Taylor, Paul D.
   Calzada, Sebastian
SO Batalleria
VL 18
PS 28-31
PD marzo 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cheilostome bryozoans are uncommon in Lower Cretaceous rocks. Therefore,
   the discovery of a specimen from the Upper Aptian of Fuente la Higuera,
   Valencia, warrants attention. Charixa sagnieri sp. nov. is introduced
   here for this new primitive (malacostegine) cheilostome. The single
   specimen encrusts the steinkern of a gastropod that was apparently
   exhumed after the sediment had hardened to provide a firm substrate
   suitable for bryozoan colonization.
C1 Taylor, Paul D.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Earth Sci, Cromwell Rd, London,
   SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

PT J
AN ZOOR14910050421
DT Article
TI THE POTENTIAL POLLINATORS OF CAESALPINIA CRISTA (LEGUMINOSAE :
   CAESALPINIOIDAE).
AU Neli, Sougrakpam (neli.sou@gmail.com) 
   Kalita, Jatin
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
PS 37-41
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Caesalpinia crista is one of the economically important medicinal plants
   of the family Leguminosae and is considered to be one of the best
   medicines to cure malaria. It is a large straggling, very thorny shrub
   with hooks and straight hard yellow prickles with nectaries at its base
   which attracts a considerable number of nectar feeding insects as it is
   an insect pollinated plant. The pollination ecology of C. crista was
   investigated through direct observation and video recording during the
   flowering period for three consecutive years (2009-2011) at Rani Reserve
   Forest, Assam, North Eastern India situated at 26[degree]01' N to
   26[degree]06' N Latitude and 91[degree]35' E to 91[degree]42' E
   Longitude. In this present study, 22 species of insects were recorded in
   association with the plant among which 10 are major pollinators and the
   remaining 12 are minor pollinators of the plant. Among the 10 pollinator
   insects, seven potential pollinators was found to be exclusively bee
   species, Apis cerana, Anthophora semperi, Xylocopa aestuens, Xylocopa
   latipes, Megachile disjuncta, Megachile latipes and Megachile sp. Future
   conservation and management of this medicinally important plant species
   needs to take into account the needs and biology of its potential
   pollinators.
C1 Neli, Sougrakpam; Gauhati Univ, Dept Zool, Guwahati, Assam, 781014,
   India, India.
EM neli.sou@gmail.com
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BD Nutrition; Diet; Feeding behaviour; Associations; Mutualism; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Insecta [Food plants / Caesalpinia crista / Conservation management;
   potential pollinators] [Foraging / Foraging behaviour / ] [Pollination /
    / ] [Assam / Rani Reserve Forest / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda
OR Insecta (Arthropoda). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14910050421
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14910050063
DT Article
TI Early Carboniferous tabulate corals from the Hiroshimaphyllum toriyamai
   zone (late Visean to early Serpukhovian) of the Akiyoshi Limestone
   Group, Yamaguchi Prefecture.
AU Niko, Shuji
SO Bulletin of the Akiyoshi-Dai Museum of Natural History
VL 48
PS 9-13
PD March 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two auloporid tabulate corals, including a pyrgiid Cladochonus sp. cf.
   C. ozawai Niko and Haikawa and a new species of a roemeriid
   Pseudoroemeripora watanabei, are described from the late Visean to early
   Serpukhovian (middle to late Early Carboniferous) Hiroshimaphyllum
   toriyamai coral zone of the Akiyoshi Limestone Group. They are collected
   from gray massive limestone of the reef fiat facies in the Okubo area,
   Yamaguchi Prefecture. The present material, here compared with C.
   ozawai, differs from the typical specimens in lacking the crowded
   tabulae. The intercorallite walls of P. watanabei partly indicate
   exceptional thickenings in comparing with the type species the genus, P.
   lenaica Koksharskaya, from Northeast Siberia, thus its generic
   identification is tentative. A close phylogenetic relationship between
   of the Akiyoshi species and P. multithecoporoides Jia from the Upper
   Carboniferous of South China is suggested.
C1 Niko, Shuji; Hiroshima Univ, Fac Integrated Arts & Sci,
   Higashihiroshima, Hiroshima, 7398521, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology

   Palaeozoic

   [Carboniferous / Early Carboniferous / ].

DT Article
TI Additional material of tabulate corals from the Millerella yowarensis
   zone (Serpukhovian, Early Carboniferous) of the Akiyoshi Limestone Group
   in the Minami-dai area, Yamaguchi Prefecture.
AU Niko, Shuji
   Haikawa, Takehiko
   Fujikawa, Masayuki
SO Bulletin of the Akiyoshi-Dai Museum of Natural History
VL 48
PS 15-18
PD March 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two undocumented species of tabulate corals, Sutherlandia sphaericus sp.
   nov. and Donetzites? sp. indet., are added to the Serpukhovian (late
   Early Carboniferous) tabulate coral fauna from the Millerella yowarensis
   zone of the Akiyoshi Limestone Group in the Minami-dai area, Yamaguchi
   Prefecture. The new species of a favositid genus Sutherlandia is similar
   with S. hasegawai Niko, Ibaraki and Tazawa from the Moscovian (middle
   Late Carboniferous) of the Omi Limestone in Niigata Prefecture and the
   Akiyoshi Limestone Group, but it differs from the younger species in
   having the much thicker intercorallite walls and the fewer mural pores
   with variable diameters and in lacking a regular arrangement of the
   proximal squamulae. Donetzites? sp. indet. is described because of its
   unusual columnar structures in the stereoplasm.

   Higashihiroshima, Hiroshima, 7398521, Japan, Japan.

DT Article
TI Abra Maruncunca, dpto. Puno, Peru, revisited: vegetation cover and
   avifauna changes over a 30-year period.
AU Robbins, Mark B. (mrobbins@ku.edu) 
   Schulenberg, Thomas S.
   Lane, Daniel F.
   Cuervo, Andres M.
   Binford, Laurence C.
   Nyari, Arpad S.
   Combe, Mariela
   Arbelaez-Cortes, Enrique
   Wehtje, Walter
   Lira-Noriega, Andres
SO Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club
VL 133
IS 1
PS 31-51
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Avifaunal inventories in 1980, 2007 and 2009 along the eastern slope of
   the Peruvian Andes at Abra Maruncunca, dpto. Puno, document the
   occurrence and change in relative abundance of 245 species. Degradation
   of forest cover with an increase in secondary vegetation probably
   explains many of the differences between the 1980 and 2009 surveys. We
   provide details for the first occurrence and clarification of the status
   in Peru for Ochre-cheeked Spinetail Synallaxis scutata, Olivaceous
   Woodcreeper Sittasomus griseicapillus viridis, Scimitar-winged Piha
   Lipaugus uropygialis, White-necked Thrush Turdus albicollis contemptus,
   Blue-browed Tanager Tangara cyanotis cyanotis, White-browed Brush Finch
   Arremon torquatus and Yellow-bellied Siskin Sporagra xanthogastra, with
   comments on the taxonomy of Roadside Hawk Rupornis magnirostris,
   Plumbeous Pigeon Patagioenas plumbea, a Pyrrhura parakeet, White-bellied
   Hummingbird Amazilia chionogaster, an antwren Herpsilochmus sp., and
   Fuscous Flycatcher Cnemotriccus fuscatus. The key for ensuring that this
   rich avifauna is preserved at this site lies in the protection of the
   relatively intact forest at the base of the massif at the north end of
   our study area.
C1 Robbins, Mark B.; Univ Kansas, Biodivers Inst, 1325 Jayhawk Blvd,
   Lawrence, KS, 66045, USA, USA.
EM mrobbins@ku.edu
OI Lira-Noriega, Andres/0000-0002-3219-0019; Arbelaez Cortes,
   Enrique/0000-0002-4350-1564

SN 0007-1595

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

   Puno; Abra Maruncunca] [Community structure /  / ] [Forest and woodland
   / Forest cover / ] [Peru / Puno, Abra Maruncunca / ].

AB The synonymies, diagnoses and bionomies of some African Lamiinae are
   proposed. One new species : Eunidia rnourgliana nov. sp., and one new

   Prioninae).

AB The genus Aesa is revised and the lectotype of A. media Lameere, 1912
   was designated. Three new species, A. iriana, A. glabra and A. nearnsi
   sp. nov. are described and variations of the type species A. media in
   Australia are indicated. A short discussion is given for the tribal
   position of this genus.

DT Article
TI A new species of Nassarius (Gastropoda: Nassariidae) from the western
   Pacific Ocean.
AU Zhang Suping (museum@qdio.ac.cn) 
SO Chinese Journal of Oceanology and Limnology
VL 31
IS 2
PS 431-434
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB This paper describes a new species of Nassarius from the South China
   Sea, which was recognized when re-sorting the collection of Nassariidae
   in the Marine Biological Museum, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao,
   China. The shells were collected during several investigations,
   including the National Comprehensive Oceanic Survey in 1958-1959, and
   the China-Vietnam Co-Investigation on Marine Resource of the Beibu Gulf
   during 1959-1962. The morphology of the shell and the radula places the
   new species of Nassarius within the subgenus Zeuxis. It is named
   Nassarius (Zeuxis) nanhaiensis sp. nov.
C1 Zhang Suping; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Oceanol, Qingdao, 266071, China,
   China.
EM museum@qdio.ac.cn

PT J
AN ZOOR14910042918
DT Article
TI Mammal and Bird Tracks from the Eocene Puget Group, Northwest
   Washington, USA.
AU Mustoe, George E. (mustoeg@wwu.edu) 
   Hopkins, Donald Q.
SO Ichnos
VL 20
IS 1
PS 36-42
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB In 1997, coal extraction at the John Henry Mine in western King County,
   Washington, USA, exposed bedding planes in Eocene sandstone that
   contained numerous bird and mammal tracks. By the time scientists
   arrived at the site several months later, the track-bearing surfaces had
   mostly been obliterated by landslides. Several track specimens were
   collected but not curated, described, or studied. In 2011, the specimens
   were found in a storage room at the University of Washington Burke
   Museum of History and Culture, triggering an investigation that yielded
   many photographs of the fossil site taken at the time of the 1997
   discovery. Perissodactyl mammal tracks are named herein as
   Oplidcatylapes eocenica ichnogenus and ichnospecies nov. Photographs
   also show a trackway containing eight footprints that have prominent
   claw impressions. These tracks are inferred to have been made by a
   creodont, but because of the absence of specimens or track casts to
   serve as holotypes, ichnotaxonomic names have not been assigned.
C1 Mustoe, George E.; Western Washington Univ, Geology MS 9080, Bellingham,
   WA, 98225, USA, USA.
EM mustoeg@wwu.edu
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1042-0940

   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Henry Mine / ] [Eocene / Lower Eocene, Puget Group / ]. 
   Fossil Miscellanea [Fossil tracks /  / Attributed to Aves] [ /  /
   Attributed to Mammalia; taxonomic implications] [Washington / King
   County, John Henry Mine / fossil tracks attributed to Aves] [ /  /
   fossil tracks attributed to Mammalia; stratigraphical distribution]
   [Eocene / Lower Eocene, Puget Group / ] [ /  / ].

   from fossil track; Possibly attributable to Perissodactyla (Mammalia)].

   attributable to Perissodactyla (Mammalia), Eocene, Washington / ]
   [Washington /  / new species; Described from fossil track; possibly
   attributable to Perissodactyla (Mammalia)] [Eocene /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14910046113
DT Article
TI Trigonostomum vanmecheleni sp nov., a new species of Trigonostomidae
   (Rhabdocoela: Dalytyphloplanida) from the channels of Venice (Italy),
   with a discussion on the T. lilliei species group.
AU Artois, T. (tom.artois@uhasselt.be) 
   Schockaert, E.
   Beenaerts, N.
   Reygel, P.
SO Italian Journal of Zoology (Modena)
VL 80
IS 1
PS 46-51
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Trigonostomum vanmecheleni nov. sp. (Rhabdocoela: Dalytyphloplanida) was
   collected from algae taken from the channels in Venice (Italy). It can
   easily be distinguished from its congeners by the detailed morphology of
   the stylet and of the bursal appendage, which is a coiled tube. Only T.
   lilliei has a bursal appendage with a comparable morphology. All
   available material of that species was also studied, leading to the
   conclusion that T. prytherchi is not a synonym of T. lilliei, as was
   proposed in earlier literature. T. prytherchi can be distinguished by
   the fact that the stylet proper is proximally bent over 180[degree],
   whereas in the other two species it is bent over 90[degree], and by the
   fact that the mantle of the stylet consists of one plate only, where it
   comprises two plates in the other two species. T. vanmecheleni nov. sp.
   can be distinguished from T. lilliei by the fact that the two plates of
   the mantle are different in shape and by the fact that the bursal
   appendage splits distally into six finer tubes. In T. lilliei the two
   plates are identical in shape and the bursal appendage splits distally
   into three to four finer tubes.
C1 Artois, T.; Ctr Environm Sci, Res Grp Zool Biodivers & Toxicol, Univ
   Campus Gebouw D, Diepenbeek, B-3590, Belgium, Belgium.
EM tom.artois@uhasselt.be
RI Artois, Tom/O-7349-2017
OI Artois, Tom/0000-0002-2491-7273; Beenaerts, Natalie/0000-0001-5655-5943
SC Zoology
SN 1125-0003
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Trigonostomum vanmecheleni [Mediterranean Sea / Italy / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Trigonostomum divae (Turbellaria): [Status, P. 47]. 
   Trigonostomum lilliei - Von Graff 1911 (Turbellaria): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 50; Removal from synonymy, Trigonostomum prytherchi Kepner
   et al 1941, p. 50]. 
   Trigonostomum prytherchi - Kepner et al 1941 (Turbellaria): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 50; Removal from synonymy, With Trigonostomum lilliei Von
   Graff 1911, p. 50]. 
   Trigonostomum vanmecheleni (Turbellaria): [Sp nov, Italy (marine), P.
   47]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14910046113

DT Article
TI Diplazontinae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) from New Zealand.
AU Ward, D.F. (wardda@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 36
IS 1
PS 30-36
PD March 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Diplazontinae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) from New Zealand is
   examined. Three new endemic species are described: Woldstedtius
   dundasius sp. nov.; W. gauldius sp. nov.; and W. titirangiensis sp. nov.
   These are the first Woldstedtius to be described from New Zealand, and
   are relatively widespread, often occurring at high altitudes. The only
   other known Diplazontinae occurring in New Zealand is the cosmopolitan
   Diplazon laetatorius (Fabricius), which is commonly found throughout the
   country.
C1 Ward, D.F.; Landcare Res, New Zealand Arthropod Collect, Private Bag
   92170, Auckland, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM wardda@landcareresearch.co.nz
OI Ward, Darren/0000-0002-4509-8553

   Australasian region; Australasia

   titirangiensis [New Zealand /  / New species].

TI Pselaphinae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) of the Three Kings Islands.
AU Thery, T.
   Leschen, R.A.B. (leschenr@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
SO New Zealand Entomologist
VL 36
IS 1
PS 37-64
PD March 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Thirteen new species and one new genus of Pselaphinae (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae) are described from the Three Kings Islands, as follows:
   Faronitae (Sagola incisa sp. nov., Sagola triregia sp. nov.);
   Euplectitae (Scabritiopsis gen. nov. (type species: Scabritiopsis caecus
   sp. nov.)); Goniaceritae (Eupines chandleri sp. nov., Eupines crosbyi
   sp. nov., Eupines tronqueti sp. nov., Eupines watti sp. nov.,
   Gastrobothrus buckleyi sp. nov.); Pselaphitae (Hamotulus pectinatus sp.
   nov., Pselaphogenius butcherae sp. nov., Pselaphogenius carltoni sp.
   nov., Pselaphogenius hodeberti sp. nov., Pselaphogenius turbotti sp.
   nov.). The genus Anabaxis (Goniaceritae) is also reported from the
   islands, though a full appreciation of the Three Kings fauna must await
   full revision of the entire New Zealand fauna.

AB Morphotaxonomy of nine species of Lyclene Moore i.e., L. humilis
   (Walker), L. obsoleta Moore, L. dharma (Moore), L. radians Moore, L.
   euprepioides (Walker), L. linga (Moore), L. spilosomoides Moore, L.
   calamaria (Moore), L. strigipennis (Herrich-Schaffer) is given in this

PT J
AN ZOOR14910045523
DT Article
TI A new scorpion species of medical importance of the genus Centruroides
   (Scorpiones: Buthidae) from the state of Guerrero, Mexico.
FT Una especie nueva de alacran del genero Centruroides de importancia
   medica (Scorpiones: Buthidae) del estado de Guerrero, Mexico.
AU Guadalupe Baldazo-Monsivaiz, Jose
   Ponce-Saavedra, Javier (javierpon@gmail.com) 
   Flores-Moreno, Miguel
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 84
IS 1
PS 100-116
PD marzo 2013
PY 2013
LA English; Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Centruroides villegasi sp. nov. from the municipality of Chilapa de
   Alvarez, Guerrero, Mexico is described. It is the nineth species of
   Centruroides reported for this state. The new species is compared with
   C. limpidus (Karsch, 1879) which is morphologically similar and inhabits
   the same geographic zone. The species C. balsasensis Ponce and Francke,
   2004, C. meisei Hoffmann, 1938, and C. tecomanus Hoffmann, 1932 are also
   compared because they are found in Guerrero and belong to the "striped
   scorpions" group (sensu Hoffmann, 1932), and therefore they are
   morphologically similar to the new species. It is a species of medical
   importance that had not been collected or recognized previously. A list
   of species of scorpions recorded for the state of Guerrero is included
   after the revision and correction of historical records.
C1 Ponce-Saavedra, Javier; Univ Michoacana San Nicolas de Hidalgo, Fac
   Biol, Edificio B-4 2O Piso,Ciudad Univ, Morelia, Michoacan, 58060,
   Mexico, Mexico.
EM javierpon@gmail.com
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Centruroides villegasi [Mexico /  / New species]. 
   Scorpiones [Mexico / Guerrero / Faunal list]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Scorpiones (Arachnida). 
   Centruroides limpidus - Karsch (Scorpiones): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   109]. 
   Centruroides meisei - Hoffman (Scorpiones): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   110]. 
   Centruroides villegasi (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 103].

TI A systematic monograph of the Recent Pentastomida, with a compilation of
   their hosts.
AU Christoffersen, M.L. (mlchrist@dse.ufpb.br) 
   De Assis, J.E.
SO Zoologische Mededelingen (Leiden)
VL 87
IS 1
PS 1-206
PD March 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We compile all published information on the Recent Pentastomida
   published to date, including complete synonyms, and species
   distributions. All host species are cited and their names updated. A
   taxonomical history of the group, a synthesis of phylogenetic
   information for the taxon, and a summary of the pentastomes by host
   groups, with accounts of the illneses they provoke, are also provided.

DT Article
TI New fossil palaeontinids (Hemiptera, Cicadomorpha, Palaeontinidae) from
   the Middle Jurassic of Daohugou, China.
AU Wang, Ying (wangying@bmnh.org.cn) 
   Shih, Chungkun
   Szwedo, Jacek
   Ren, Dong
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 1
PS 19-30
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Wang, Y., Shih, C., Szwedo, J. & Ren, D. iFirst article. New fossil
   palaeontinids (Hemiptera, Cicadomorpha, Palaeontinidae) from the Middle
   Jurassic of Daohugou, China. Alcheringa, 112. ISSN 0311-5518. A new
   genus and species assigned to the extinct family Palaeontinidae,
   Synapocossus sciacchitanoae Wang, Shih & Ren, is described from the
   Middle Jurassic of Daohugou in Inner Mongolia, China. This new genus is
   established based on well-preserved fossil specimens with body and
   complete forewings and hind wings. It differs from other described
   genera by the following characters: small body size, RP and M1
   coalescing for an interval on the forewings and M3+4 without bifurcation
   on the hind wings. The RP coalescence with M1 in Synapocossus Wang, Shih
   & Ren previously reported only in Turgaiella Becker-Migdisova & Wootton,
   seems to be associated with strengthening of the anterior wing margin.
   The intra-specific and individual variations of Synapocossus and
   numerous other insect fossils of northeastern China probably indicate
   long-lasting ecological stresses and a competitive environment in the
   Middle Jurassic to Early Cretaceous ecosystems.Synapocossus
   sciacchitanoae Wang, Shih & Ren;Palaeontinidae RP?M1, M3+4, Synapocossus
   Wang, Shih & Ren RP M1 Turgaiella Becher-Migdisova & Wootton,
   ?????????????????Synapocossus???????????????????????????????????????????
   ????
C1 Wang, Ying; Beijing Museum Nat Hist, 126 Tianqiao South St, Beijing,
   100050, China, China.
EM wangying@bmnh.org.cn
RI Szwedo, Jacek/B-4774-2013; Szwedo, Jacek/O-1442-2019
OI Szwedo, Jacek/0000-0002-2796-9538; Szwedo, Jacek/0000-0002-2796-9538

AB Dong Q.P., Yao Y.Z. & Ren D., 2012. A new species of Progonocimicidae
   (Hemiptera, Coleorrhyncha) from the Middle Jurassic of China.
   Alcheringa, 17. ISSN 0311-5518. A new fossil species, Cicadocoris
   assimilis, of the family Progonocimicidae is described from the Middle
   Jurassic Jiulongshan Formation of Daohugou Village, Inner Mongolia,
   China. Cicadocoris Becker-Migdisova, 1958 and Mesocimex Hong, 1983 show
   no significant differences and are considered to be synonyms. Qiuping
   Dong (qiupingdong@gmail.com), Yunzhi Yao* (Corresponding author:
   yaoyz100@gmail.com) and Dong Ren (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn), Key
   Laboratory of Insect Evolution and Environmental Changes, Capital Normal
   University, Beijing 100048, PR China. *Also affiliated with State Key
   Laboratory of Palaeobiology and Stratigraphy (Nanjing Institute of
   Geology and Palaeontology, CAS), Nanjing 210008, PR China. Received
   30.3.2012; revised 21.5.2012; accepted 7.6.2012.

TI Description of Systenobythere gen. nov (Ostracoda, Crustacea) from the
   late Miocene of southeastern Australia with comments on its
   problematical taxonomic and palaeoecological affinities.
AU Warne, Mark T. (mwarne@deakin.edu.au) 
   Whatley, Robin C.
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 1
PS 79-86
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Warne, M.T. & Whatley, R.C. iFirst article. Description of
   Systenobythere gen. nov. (Ostracoda, Crustacea) from the late Miocene of
   southeastern Australia with comments on its problematical taxonomic and
   palaeoecological affinities. Alcheringa, 18. ISSN 0311-5518. A new
   ostracod genus and species, Systenobythere archboldi, is described from
   late Miocene open neritic strata of southeastern Australia. Specimens
   occur in argillaceous glauconitic sands deposited in offshore
   continental shelf settings that were periodically influenced by coastal
   upwelling. Systenobythere archboldi possesses an adductor muscle scar
   pattern typical of the Bythocytheridae, but has a pentodont hinge and
   sieve-type normal pore canals atypical of this family.

   and Texas, USA. Alcheringa, 118. ISSN 0311-5518. The holotype of the
   nominal lamniform shark Pseudoisurus' vraconensis comprises an isolated
   tooth from a late Albian stratum at Besakty, Mangyshlak, Kazakhstan. Its
   stratigraphical provenance indicates that it is of Mortoniceras
   perinflatum Zone-age or somewhat older. It is indistinguishable at the
   species level from isolated teeth from the Mortoniceras rostratum Zone
   of the Pawpaw Shale in northeast Texas. Abundant teeth of P'.
   vraconensis-type from slightly younger strata close to the
   AlbianCenomanian boundary at Kolbay, eastern Mangyshlak, Kazakhstan,
   enabled the reconstruction of a dentition adhering to the dental
   blueprint of Cretoxyrhina, clarifying the generic identity of P'.
   vraconensis. In the Kolbay population, the distal lobe of the root on
   the three probable third upper anterior teeth at hand is not
   labiolingually compressed relative to the mesial lobe. Labiolingual
   flattening of the root lobe facing the mesial side of the intermediate
   bar is a characteristic feature of modern lamnids and may reflect
   limited accommodation space for a thick root lobe to form at the distal
   margin of the anterior hollow. An intermediate bar adds structural
   strength to the anterior part of the palatoquadrate while isolating the
   upper anterior teeth, facilitating deep penetration by their enlarged
   cusps. Individuals of Cretoxyrhina from the late Coniacian to earliest
   Campanian Smoky Hill Chalk in Kansas display a strongly disjunct
   heterodonty in the anterior half of the upper jaw dentition. This
   so-called lamnoid tooth pattern' is regarded by some researchers as a
   synapomorphy of the Lamniformes. The dwarfed teeth creating the lamnoid
   tooth pattern' in Smoky Hill Chalk individuals are seemingly matched by
   relatively larger, corresponding teeth in the 15 million years older C.
   vraconensis. The probable weakening of the disjunct upper jaw
   heterodonty in Cretoxyrhina with increasing geological age indicates
   that the lamnoid tooth pattern' might have evolved independently in two
   or more lamniform clades. ?????Pseudoisurus'vraconensis???????????,

TI Gracilitheca and Nephrotheca (Hyolitha, Orthothecida) in the Cambrian of
   the Barrandian area, Czech Republic.
AU Valent, Martin
   Fatka, Oldrich (martin_valent@nm.cz) 
   Marek, Ladislav
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 1
PS 115-124
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB VALENT, M., FATKA, O. & MAREK, L., iFirst article. Gracilitheca and
   Nephrotheca (Hyolitha, Orthothecida) in the Cambrian of the Barrandian
   area, Czech Republic. Alcheringa, 110. ISSN 0311-5518. Five orthothecid
   hyoliths, Gracilitheca mirabilis sp. nov., Gracilitheca triangularis sp.
   nov., Gracilitheca sp., Nephrotheca betula sp. nov. and Nephrotheca sp.
   are described from the middle' Cambrian Buchava Formation of the
   SkryjeTyovice Basin in the Czech Republic. The new forms are based on
   about forty well-preserved external and internal moulds of conchs;
   opercula of all species remain unknown. Stratigraphic ranges and
   geographic distributions within the Skryje Tyovice Basin are established
   for all taxa.

AB Yang, G., Yao, Y.Z. & Ren, D., iFirst. Poljanka strigosa, a new species
   of Protopsyllidiidae (Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha) from the Middle
   Jurassic of China. Alcheringa, 16. ISSN 0311-5518. A new fossil species,
   Poljanka strigosa sp. nov., of the extinct family Protopsyllidiidae is
   described from the Middle Jurassic Jiulongshan Formation of Daohugou
   Village, Inner Mongolia, China. The new species is characterized by
   wings bearing long, stiff setae that are evident as stained impressions
   in the fine sedimentary rock. Comparison between Protopsyllidiidae and
   extant psylloids suggests that Protopsyllidiidae is probably closely
   related to extant psylloids. ?????????????????????????Poljanka strigosa

TI A new large fossil species of Tiliqua (Squamata; Scincidae) from the
   Pliocene of the Wellington Caves (New South Wales, Australia).
AU Cernansky, Andrej (cernansky.paleontology@gmail.com) 
   Hutchinson, Mark N.
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 1
PS 131-136
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB eransky, A. & Hutchinson, M.N., 2012. A new large fossil species of
   Tiliqua (Squamata; Scincidae) from the Pliocene of the Wellington Caves
   (New South Wales, Australia). Alcheringa, 16. ISSN 0311-5518. We
   describe an isolated frontal bone referable to a new species, Tiliqua
   laticephala (Scincidae), from the Pliocene Big Sink doline of the
   Wellington Caves, central eastern New South Wales, Australia. The bone
   is very robust, is unusually broad and thick, especially around the
   bases of the subolfactory processes and represents a large and heavily
   built lizard. The fossil has multiple fragmentary osteoderms in the
   frontal region, showing asymmetry in shape and thickness that do not
   correspond to the more regularly arranged anterior head shields of other
   scincoids. The specimen shares two unusual character states with extant
   Tiliqua, especially the large armoured species, T. Rugosa. Other large
   skinks related to T. Rugosa (other Tiliqua spp., Corucia zebrata,
   Egernia cunninghamii, Bellatorias major, Liopholis kintorei) are less
   similar in terms of frontal shape, thickness, sculpture, osteoderm
   ornamentation, and positioning of adjacent bones. ??????????Tiliqua
   laticephala (Scincidae) ????????????????????????????????????Big Sink
   ?????????, ?????(??????????????), ???????????????????????, ????????,
   ?????scincoids?????????????????Tiliqua, ??????????T. Rugosa,
   ?????????????T. Rugosa ??????????????(Tiliqua spp., Corucia zebrata,
   Egernia cunninghamii, Bellatorias major, Liopholis kintorei)
   ???????????????????????????????

DT Article
TI Non-pollinating Fig Wasps Decrease Pollinator and Seed Production in
   Ficus andicola (Moraceae).
AU Cardona, William (wcardona@wcs.org) 
   Kattan, Gustavo
   Chacon de Ulloa, Patricia
SO Biotropica
VL 45
IS 2
PS 203-208
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 67
AB Fig trees ( Ficus spp.) and Agaonine fig-wasps participate in an
   obligate mutualism. Fig wasps can only develop within fig inflorescences
   (syconia) and they are the only organisms capable of pollinating fig
   flowers. Other non-pollinating wasps that lay eggs by inserting their
   ovipositors from the outside can also develop in syconia. These
   parasitic wasps may be parasitoids of either pollinating or other
   non-pollinating wasps, or form galls in fig flowers or other tissues.
   Depending on this interaction, parasitic wasps may have various effects
   on the production of pollinating wasps and seeds. Wasps in the genus
   Idarnes, which parasitize New World figs (subgenus Urostigma), have an
   effect on wasp production but not on seed production. Heterandrium spp.,
   which have short ovipositors and lay on external flowers, are infrequent
   and no effect on seed production has been documented. In the Colombian
   Andes, Idarnes spp. and Heterandrium spp. are the most frequent
   parasites of the Ficus andicola Pegoscapus sp. mutualism, affecting 62
   and 43 percent of syconia, respectively. Controlling for other factors
   that influence wasp and seed production, such as number of foundresses,
   syconium size and tree, we found that Idarnes reduced pollinator
   production by almost half but did not reduce seed production, whereas
   Heterandrium reduced seed production by 40 percent, and marginally
   affected pollinator production. Our results provide the first clear
   documentation of Heterandrium spp. impact on fig seed production.
   Whether the relative abundance of this genus is a generalized phenomenon
   in montane forest remains to be determined. Resumen Los arboles del
   genero Ficus y las avispas de la subfamilia Agaoninae participan en un
   mutualismo obligado. Estas avispas solo pueden desarrollarse dentro de
   las inflorescencias (siconos) de estos arboles y son practicamente los
   unicos organismos que pueden fecundar sus flores. Otras avispas no
   polinizadoras ponen huevos en los siconos, insertando sus ovipositores a
   traves de la pared externa. Estas avispas parasitas pueden ser
   parasitoides de las polinizadoras o de otras avispas no polinizadoras, o
   formar agallas en las flores u otros tejidos. Dependiendo de esta
   interaccion, las avispas parasitas pueden tener efectos sobre la
   produccion de avispas polinizadoras y de semillas. Las avispas del
   genero Idarnes son parasitos en Ficus del Nuevo Mundo del subgenero
   Urostigma. Algunos estudios han demostrado que estas afectan la
   produccion de avispas polinizadoras, pero no afectan la produccion de
   semillas. Las avispas del genero Heterandrium, las cuales tienen
   ovipositores cortos y ponen sus huevos en las flores mas cercanas a la
   pared del sicono, son poco comunes y no se ha documentado un efecto
   claro sobre la produccion de semillas. En el mutualismo entre Ficus
   andicola y Pegoscapus sp. en los Andes de Colombia, Idarnes spp. y
   Heterandrium spp. son las avispas parasitas mas comunes y parasitan
   respectivamente 62% y 43% de los siconos. Teniendo en cuenta otros
   factores que influyen la produccion de avispas polinizadoras y semillas,
   como son el numero de avispas fundadoras, el tamano del sicono y el
   arbol, encontramos que Idarnes redujo la produccion de polinizadores
   casi a la mitad, pero no tuvo efecto sobre la produccion de semillas.
   Por su parte Heterandrium redujo la produccion de semillas en 40% y tuvo
   un efecto marginal sobre los polinizadores. Estos resultados proveen la
   primera documentacion clara del impacto de avispas del genero
   Heterandrium sobre la produccion de semillas. Falta por determinarse si
   la abundancia relativa de este genero es un fenomeno generalizado en los
   bosques montanos.
C1 Cardona, William; Wildlife Conservat Soc Programa Colombia, Carrera 25
   4-39, Cali, 760043, Colombia, Colombia.
EM wcardona@wcs.org
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 0006-3606
BD Reproduction; Reproductive system; Associations; Habitat; Terrestrial
   habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Heterandrium; Idarnes [Ovipositor / Ovipositor length / Plant
   mutualists; effect on pollinator & seed production] [Mutualism / Ficus
   andicola (plant) / ] [Forest and woodland / Forest / ] [Colombia /
   Central Cordillera / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Chalcidoidea, Agaonidae
OR Heterandrium (Agaonidae). 
   Idarnes (Agaonidae).

TI ON THE IDENTITIES OF PILUMNOPEUS CONVEXUS MACCAGNO, 1936, AND P.
   SALOMONENSIS WARD, 1942, FROM THE INDIAN OCEAN, WITH A NOTE ON P. RIUI
   TAKEDA, 2001 (DECAPODA, BRACHYURA, PILUMNIDAE).
AU Ghory, Farhana
   Ng, Peter K.L. (peterng@nus.edu.sg) 
   Kazmi, Quddusi B.
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 3
PS 301-312
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of the western Indian Ocean pilumnid crab, Pilumnopeus
   convexus (Maccagno, 1936) (type locality: Ethiopia) is discussed and the
   poorly known P. salomonensis Ward, 1942 (type locality: Chagos
   Archipelago) is shown to be its junior synonym. Pilumnopeus sinensis
   Balss, 1933 (from China) is transferred to Serenepilumnus Turkay &
   Schumacher, 1985. Pilumnopeus riui Takeda, 2001 (from Hainan) is herein
   synonymized with Aniptumnus quadridentatus (De Man, 1895). Pilumnopeus ?
   laevimanus Cano, 1889 (from South America) is removed from the genus; it
   is more likely to be a species of Panopeidae or Pseudorhombilidae.

TI PARAPERCICOLA INFLATA N. SP (COPEPODA, CHONDRACANTHIDAE) PARASITIC ON
   THE RED BIGEYE, PRIACANTHUS MACRACANTHUS CUVIER, FROM TAIWAN.
AU Ho, Ju-Shey
   Liu, Wei-Cheng (wchengliu@gmail.com) 
   Lin, Ching-Long
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 3
PS 357-366
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of chondracanthid copepod, Parapercicola inflata n. sp.,
   parasitic in the nasal cavity of the red bigeye, Priacanthus
   macracanthus Cuvier, 1829, caught off the southern coast of Taiwan, is
   described. This is the second species of a recently established genus,
   Parapercicola Ho, Liu & Lin, 2011. It is distinguishable from its only
   known congener, R formosana Ho, Liu & Lin, 2011, in having in the female
   (1) a short trunk that is distinctly wider than long, (2) a greatly
   inflated antennule, (3) a labrum with knobs on the free posterior
   margin, (4) a less reduced endopod in legs 1 and 2; and in the male in
   having (5) a spinulose terminal process on the caudal ramus and (6) a
   maxilliped with a patch of denticles on the second segment.
C1 Liu, Wei-Cheng; Natl Chiayi Univ, Dept Aquat Biosci, 300 Univ Rd,
   Chiayi, 60083, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM wchengliu@gmail.com

   Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   host].

DT Article
TI Generic revision of Argiolestidae (Odonata), with four new genera.
AU Kalkman, Vincent J. (kalkman@naturalis.nl) 
   Theischinger, Gunther
SO International Journal of Odonatology
VL 16
IS 1
PS 1-52
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The subfamily Argiolestinae is raised to family level to include all
   zygopteran genera in which the gills of the larvae are flat and held in
   a horizontal plane. A diagnosis of the family is given and characters
   for both adults and larvae are presented. The family is divided into two
   subfamilies based on characters in the genital ligula, with the
   subfamily Argiolestinae found in Australasia east of Huxley's Line and
   the subfamily Podolestinae found in Africa and Asia west of Huxley's
   Line. Four genera are newly described: Eoargiolestes (New Caledonia,
   type species Sympecma ochracea Montrouzier, 1864), Luzonargiolestes
   (Philippines, type species Argiolestes realensis Gapud & Recuenco,
   1993), Solomonargiolestes (Bougainville, Papua New Guinea and Malaita,
   Solomon Islands, type species Argiolestes bougainville Kalkman, 2008)
   and Pyrrhargiolestes (Papua New Guinea, type species Argiolestes sidonia
   Martin, 1909). In addition Metagrion (type species Argiolestes
   postnodalis Selys, 1878) and Wahnesia (type species Argiolestes kirbyi
   Forster, 1900), two genera not in use for over 70 years, are reinstated.
   Based on molecular data the African genera Neurolestes and Nesolestes
   have been shown to be good genera and are here treated as such,
   Nesolestes nigeriensis is transferred to Neurolestes. All 20 genera
   included in Argiolestidae are discussed, with type species, key
   characters of adults, distribution and habitat being given. In addition
   a diagnosis is presented for each genus and information is given on
   their identification together with a map of the distribution of the
   genus and scanning electron microscope images of the genital ligula of
   most genera. A key to the genera of the Australasian region is presented
   and keys to the species of Caledargiolestes, Caledopteryx and Podopteryx
   are given. New distributional records of Caledargiolestes, Caledopteryx,
   Luzonargiolestes, Solomonargiolestes and Podopteryx are provided.
C1 Kalkman, Vincent J.; Nat Biodivers Ctr, POB 9517, Leiden, NL-2300 RA,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM kalkman@naturalis.nl
SC Zoology
SN 1388-7890
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type species;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status;
   Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Argiolestidae [Checklists / Taxonomic checklist / Systematics] [Land
   zones /  / Distribution] [Australasia /  / Key to genera]. 
   Caledargiolestes uniseries; Caledopteryx maculata; Caledopteryx sarasini
   [New Caledonia /  / New record]. 
   Luzonargiolestes cf. baltazarae [Philippines / Luzon / New record]. 
   Podopteryx roseonotata; Podopteryx selysi [Indonesia / Papua / New
   record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

OR Allolestes - Selys 1869 (Odonata): [Referred to, New subfamily
   Podolestinae, p. 42]. 
   Argiolestes - Selys 1862 (Odonata): [Removal from synonymy, Metagrion

DT Article
TI Two new species of Pyrrhargiolestes, with a key to the males (Odonata:
   Argiolestidae).
AU Kalkman, Vincent J. (kalkman@naturalis.nl) 
   Richards, Stephen J.
   Polhemus, Dan A.
SO International Journal of Odonatology
VL 16
IS 1
PS 53-65
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species belonging to the endemic New Guinea genus
   Pyrrhargiolestes are described from Papua New Guinea: P. lamington sp.
   nov. (holotype: Mount Lamington, Oro Province, dep. in RMNH) and P. yela
   sp. nov. (holotype: Rossel Island, Milne Bay Province, dep. in USNM).
   The presumed male of P. aulicus is described for the first time. New
   records and remarks are provided for P. angulatus, P. kula, P. sidonia
   and P. tenuispinus. A key to the males of all species of
   Pyrrhargiolestes, information on habitat and a map of the known
   distributions are given.

   Netherlands, Netherlands.

PT J

DT Article
TI Description of Rhinocypha taiwana sp. nov. from Taiwan, with a
   preliminary molecular phylogenetic analysis of the Rhinocypha
   drusilla-group (Odonata: Chlorocyphidae).
AU Wang, Liang-Jong (ljwang23@ms17.hinet.net) 
   Cherng, Jyh-Jong
   Chang, Yung-Jen
   Jiang, Jin-Li
SO International Journal of Odonatology
VL 16
IS 1
PS 93-107
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Rhinocypha taiwana Wang & Chang, sp. nov. is described and illustrated
   for both sexes. The genetic distance of the cytochrome c oxidase I (COI)
   gene in R. taiwana and related species ranges from 4.2% to 10.4%. R.
   taiwana is shown to be a good species based on morphological and genetic
   criteria. It also is clearly retrieved as a distinct species based on
   COI phylogenetic analysis. The R. drusilla group is proposed and defined
   by a combination of characteristics which distinguish them from all
   other Rhinocypha species: male abdomen with reddish orange markings and
   S2 with a unique dorsal spade-shaped or similar marking. A key to the
   males of the six species of the R. drusilla group is provided. Two
   morphologically distinct continental species, R. drusilla and R. arguta,
   are shown to have a rather small genetic distance, only 1.21.7%. More
   material from the continental populations of this group is needed for
   further morphological and molecular studies.
C1 Wang, Liang-Jong; Taiwan Forestry Res Inst, Div Forest Protect, Taipei,
   Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM ljwang23@ms17.hinet.net
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1388-7890
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Rhinocypha drusilla group [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny /
   Systematics] [Asia /  / distribution]. 
   Rhinocypha taiwana [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Odonata
OR Rhinocypha drusilla group (Odonata): [Key to species, Males, p. 103]. 
   Rhinocypha taiwana - Wang & Chang 2013 (Odonata): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P.
   94].

PT J

PM 23224640
DT Article
TI Caryospora cherrughi sp n. (Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) infecting Falco
   cherrug in Saudi Arabia.
AU Alfaleh, F.A.
   Alyousif, M.S.
   Al-Shawa, Y.R.
   Al-Quraishy, S. (guraishi@yahoo.com) 
SO Parasitology Research
VL 112
IS 3
PS 971-974
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The oocysts of Caryospora cherrughi sp. n. were described from the feces
   of the saker falcon, Falco cherrug, collected from the falcon market in
   Riyadh City, Saudi Arabia. The prevalence of infection was 21.4 %
   (15/70). The majority of the oocysts examined had completed sporulation
   within 64-84 h at 24 [plus or minus] 2 A[degree]C. Sporulated oocysts
   are ovoid in shape, measuring 32.1 x 29.3 (30.7-34.5 x 27.7-29.8) [mu]m;
   shape index (L/W) is 1.1 (1.04-1.27) [mu]m. The oocyst wall is smooth
   and bilayered. Micropyle, polar granule, and oocyst residuum are absent.
   Sporocysts are ellipsoidal, measuring 24.1 x 19.6 (23.0-25.5 x
   18.7-20.5) [mu]m; with a smooth single-layered wall, but there is no
   Stieda body. The sporocyst residuum is present as numerous small
   granules. Sporozoites are banana-shaped, blunt at one end, and slightly
   tapered at the other, each with a large single refractile body. C.
   cherrughi sp. n. is the third caryosporian species described from F.
   cherrug.
C1 Al-Quraishy, S.; King Saud Univ, Dept Zool, Riyadh, 11451, Saudi Arabia,
   Saudi Arabia.
EM guraishi@yahoo.com
RI Alquraishy, Saleh/R-3570-2016
OI Al Faleh, Faleh/0000-0003-2458-4541
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0932-0113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Caryospora cherrughi [Avian hosts / Falco cherrug / New parasite
   species] [Saudi Arabia /  / New species from avian host]. 
   Falco cherrug [Protozoan parasites / Caryospora cherrughi / New parasite
   species] [Saudi Arabia /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Protozoans; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Falconiformes, Falconidae,
   Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Coccidia
OR Falco cherrug (Falconidae): [Host]. 
   Caryospora cherrughi (Coccidia): [Sp nov, Saudi Arabia, Parasite of
   Falco cherrug (Aves), p. 972; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036929

AN ZOOR14909036934
PM 23269510
DT Article
TI Studies on Trichodinid and Chilodonellid Ciliophorans (Protozoa:
   Ciliophora) in the Indian freshwater and estuarine fishes with
   description of Trichodinella sunderbanensis sp nov and Trichodina
   nandusi sp nov.
AU Mitra, Amlan Kumar (amlan_mitra@hotmail.com) 
   Bandyopadhyay, Probir K.
   Gong, Yingchun
SO Parasitology Research
VL 112
IS 3
PS 1077-1085
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 21
AB A comprehensive icthyoparasotological survey among estuarine and
   freshwater fishes of West Bengal, India revealed Trichodinella
   sunderbanensis sp. nov. and Trichodina acuta Lom, 1961 from an estuarine
   fish Mystus gulio (Hamilton, 1822) from the Vidyadhari river; Trichodina
   nandusi sp. nov. from a freshwater fish, Nandus nandus
   (Hamilton-Buchanan); Chilodonella hexasticha (Kiernik, 1909) Kahl, 1931
   from freshwater fishes Labeo rohita (Hamilton, 1822); and Cyprinus
   carpio Linnaeus, 1758 from the Rupnarayan river. Taxonomic description
   of all the species based on wet silver nitrate impregnation method along
   with additional comments based on scanning electron microscopic
   descriptions of T. nandusi sp. nov. are also provided in this paper.
   Prevalence rate, morphometric parameters and comparisons with closely
   related species are also discussed.

PM 23269511
DT Article
TI Molecular and morphological investigations of Sarcocystis corvusi sp nov
   from the jackdaw (Corvus monedula).
AU Prakas, Petras (petrasprakas@yahoo.com) 
   Kutkiene, Liuda
   Butkauskas, Dalius
   Sruoga, Aniolas
   Zalakevicius, Mecislovas
SO Parasitology Research
VL 112
IS 3
PS 1163-1167
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 10
AB One type of sarcocyst was found in two of eight investigated jackdaws
   (Corvus monedula) and proposed as Sarcocystis corvusi sp. nov. By light
   microscope, cysts resembled a thick thread and were very long (the
   largest fragment found amounted to 6 mm) and relatively thin (up to 60
   [mu]m). The cyst wall measured <1 [mu]m and seemed smooth. Using a
   computerized image analysis system, knolls, which resembled protrusions,
   were visible on the wall surface. Ultrastructurally, the cyst wall was
   wavy and reached up to 1.1 [mu]m. The waves were of different heights
   and resembled low protrusions. The parasitophorous vacuolar membrane had
   many invaginations. Lancet- or orange segment-shaped cystozoites were
   5.9-7.3 [mu]m long. These sarcocysts had type-1 tissue cyst wall.
   According to 18S rRNA, 28S rRNA genes and ITS-1 region sequences, it was
   shown that S. corvusi is a genetically separate species. On the basis of
   these genetic markers, S. corvusi was most closely related to S.
   columbae, S. calchasi and S. wobeseri which parasitize birds and are
   characterized by the same type of sarcocyst wall.
C1 Prakas, Petras; Nat Res Ctr, Inst Ecol, Akad 2, Vilnius, LT-08412,
   Lithuania, Lithuania.
EM petrasprakas@yahoo.com
OI Prakas, Petras/0000-0002-5115-2659
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0932-0113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Corvus monedula [Protozoan parasites / Sarcocystis corvusi / New
   parasite species] [Lithuania /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
   Sarcocystis corvusi [Avian hosts / Corvus monedula / New parasite
   species] [Lithuania /  / New species from avian host]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Protozoans; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Corvidae, Protozoa,
   Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Coccidia
OR Corvus monedula (Corvidae): [Host]. 
   Sarcocystis corvusi (Coccidia): [Sp nov, Lithuania, Parasite of Corvus
   monedula (Aves), p. 1165; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036939

DT Article
TI To knowledge of leaf-beetles of the genus Cystocnemis (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae).
AU Mikhailov, Yu.E. (yuemikhailov@gmail.com) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 3
PS 300-312
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 7
AB TO KNOWLEDGE OF LEAF-BEETLES OF THE GENUS CYSTOCNEMIS (COLEOPTERA,
   CHRYSOMELIDAE) Yu. E. Mikhailov Ural State Forestry-Engineering
   University, Yekaterinburg 620100, Russia e-mail: yuemikhailov@gmail.com
   Four subspecies of Cystocnemis discoidea were identified; two subspecies
   are described as new for science, and ssp. gebleri was resurrected from
   synonymy. Pathways of speciation in highland-hollow landscapes are
   discussed. The alpine subspecies oreas ssp. n. has an altibiome
   disjunction with the nominotypic subspecies. A similarity of the alpine
   C. discoidea subspecies with species of the subgenus Entomomela was
   found to be a result of permanent confusion of these taxa
   representatives. The subgenus Entomomela is transferred from the genus
   Oreomela to the genus Cystocnemis. A key for the identification of
   species and subspecies of the enlarged genus Cystocnemis is given.
C1 Mikhailov, Yu.E.; Ural State Forestry Engn Univ, Yekaterinburg, 620100,
   Russia, Russia.
EM yuemikhailov@gmail.com
RI Михайлов, Юрий/AAI-5068-2020

SN 0044-5134

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Two new species of the family Actinolaimidae (Nematoda) from water
   bodies of Vietnam.
AU Gagarin, V.G. (gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Gusakov, V.A.
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 3
PS 359-365
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 15
AB TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE FAMILY ACTINOLAIMIDAE (NEMATODA) FROM WATER
   BODIES OF VIETNAM V. G. Gagarin, V. A. Gusakov Institute for Biology of
   Inland Waters, Russian Academy of Sciences, Borok, Yaroslavl Oblast
   152742, Russia gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru Two new species of free-living
   nematodes from freshwater bodies of Vietnam are described and
   illustrated. Paractinolaimoides camranhius sp. n. differs from P. unicus
   Khan, Ahmad et Jairajpuri 1994 in the narrower labial region, shorter
   odontophore, shorter tail in females, longer prerectum in females and
   shorter spicules. Neoactinolaimus tenuis sp. n. is close to N.
   duplicidentatus (Andrassy 1968) and N. tepidus Andrassy 1997 and differs
   from the first in the less long tail in females, shorter prerectum in
   females, less number of supplements in males and shorter spicules. It
   differs from N. tepidus in the wider labial region, longer odontostyle,
   less number of supplements in males and longer body in females.
C1 Gagarin, V.G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol Inland Waters, Borok,
   Yaroslavl Oblast, 152742, Russia, Russia.
EM gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru

   Grigorievich/A-8438-2017
OI Gusakov, Vladimir A./0000-0002-9657-5049; 
SC Zoology
SN 0044-5134
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Neoactinolaimus tenuis; Paractinolaimoides camranhius [Vietnam /  / New
   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes

   [Diagnostic characters, P. 364].

DT Article
TI Phaenna gibbosa sp n. (Copepoda, Calanoida, Phaennidae) from the
   Northwestern Atlantic.
AU Andronov, V.N. (vandro@mail.ru) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 3
PS 366-370
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 4
AB PHAENNA GIBBOSA SP. N. (COPEPODA, CALANOIDA, PHAENNIDAE) FROM THE
   NORTHWESTERN ATLANTIC V.N. Andronov Shirshov Institute of Oceanology,
   Atlantic Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Kaliningrad 236000, Russia
   e-mail: vandro@mail.ru, andronov@ioran.baltnet.ru A female of Phaenna
   gibbosa sp.n. is described and illustrated. Three adult females (2.05,
   2.40 14 (sic) 2.55 mm), copepodite stages V (two females and six males),
   and one CIV male were found in the planktonic samples from the
   northwestern Atlantic, to the west of La Manche. The main morphological
   differences between the new species and the only known species of the
   same genus, Ph. spinifera Claus, include the cephalon shape, shape of
   the genital segment in ventral and lateral view, and the presence of
   strongly reduced P5. The most striking feature of all the examined
   copepodte stages and adult females of Ph. gibbosa is the presence of a
   large "hump" on the back side of the cephalon.
C1 Andronov, V.N.; Russian Acad Sci, PP Shirshov Oceanol Inst, Kaliningrad,
   236000, Russia, Russia.
EM vandro@mail.ru
RI Andronov, Vladimir/L-1947-2016

   Ocean

DT Article
TI Liolaemus carlosgarini and Liolaemus riodamas (Squamata: Liolaemidae),
   two new species of lizards lacking precloacal pores, from Andean areas
   of central Chile.
AU Esquerre, Damien (damien.esquerre@anu.edu.au) 
   Nunez, Herman
   Alejandro Scolaro, Jose
SO Zootaxa
VL 3619
IS 4
PS 428-452
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 2
U2 11
AB Most of the lizards of the Liolaemus genus present precloacal pores in
   males, with few exceptions in species of the lineomaculatus and
   neuquensis groups, and in the elongatus-kriegi complex. The
   elongatus-kriegi complex, belonging to the Liolaemus (sensu stricto)
   subgenus, is composed of medium sized, saxicolous, viviparous and
   insectivorous or omnivorous lizards, distributed between the Andean and
   Patagonian zones of Chile and Argentina. We reviewed the taxonomic
   history of this group, and we describe two new species, Liolaemus
   carlosgarini, found in the vicinity of the Maule Lagoon, in the Maule
   Region, Chile, and Liolaemus riodamas, described from the population
   that was originally designated as Liolaemus cf. ceii, from Las Damas
   River, near the Termas del Flaco locality, in the Libertador Bernardo
   O'Higgins Region, thereby based on this research L. ceii is eliminated
   from the species belonging to Chile. Both species have as a diagnostic
   character the absence of precloacal pores, and we suggest here their
   presumptive systematic relationships in Liolaemus. We analyzed ten
   species of Liolaemus, in order to perform a phylogenetic analysis based
   on external morphology, using mostly squamation and morphometric
   characters. The analysis was performed using PAUP, with the Maximum
   Parsimony criterion. In addition, through diaphanisation, we studied and
   described the osteology of the new species. We conclude that species
   lacking precloacal pores do not form a monophyletic group, and that
   constructing a phylogeny using only external morphology, at least for
   this group of reptiles, is insufficient to establish solid phyletic
   relationships. Other sort of characters should complement the
   morphological ones.
C1 Esquerre, Damien; Museo Nacl Hist Nat, Casilla 787, Santiago De Chile,
   Chile.
EM damien.esquerre@anu.edu.au
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Liolaemus carlosgarini; Liolaemus riodamas [Chile /  / New species]. 
   Liolaemus ceii [Chile /  / Removal from faunal list]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Liolaemus carlosgarini (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 431]. 
   Liolaemus ceii (Iguanidae). 
   Liolaemus riodamas (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 439]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036960
DA 2020-09-17

TI A contribution to the systematics of Neotropical Tanytarsus van der
   Wulp: first descriptions from Ecuador (Diptera: Chironomidae:
   Tanytarsini).
AU Gilka, Wojciech (wojciech.gilka@biol.ug.edu.pl) 
   Zakrzewska, Marta
SO Zootaxa
VL 3619
IS 4
PS 453-459
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB First specific records of Tanytarsus van der Wulp from the Ecuadorian
   mainland based on detailed descriptions are presented. Tanytarsus
   cayambe sp. nov. shows an interesting set of characters known from
   several Neotropical Tanytarsus as well as from species of the recurvatus
   group of the northern distribution. Tanytarsus cotopaxi sp. nov. is
   placed in the riopreto species group; as a result an emended diagnosis
   for adult males of the group is proposed. The diagnostic description of
   Tanytarsus curvicristatus Contreras-Lichtenberg is also complemented.

TI A new species of the Callophrys mystaphia Miller, 1913-group from Iran
   (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae: Eumaeini).
AU Krupitsky, Anatoly V. (nephrurus@yandex.ru) 
   Kolesnichenko, Kirill A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3619
IS 4
PS 460-466
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species, recently misinterpreted as Callophrys mystaphia Miller,
   1913, Callophrys mystaphioides Krupitsky & Kolesnichenko sp. n., is
   described from Central Iran (Esfahan Province). The new species differs
   from C. mystaphia in the combination of external characters and
   morphology of genitalia. Possible relations of C. mystaphia-species
   group with other Palaearctic Callophrys are discussed.

TI The first palpimanid spiders from Bolivia: two new species of the genus
   Otiothops MacLeay, and the female of Fernandezina pulchra Biraben
   (Araneae: Palpimanidae: Otiothopinae).
AU Piacentini, Luis N. (piacentini@macn.gov.ar) 
   Avila Calero, Sergio L.
   Perez, Marianela E.
   Grismado, Cristian J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3619
IS 4
PS 491-500
PD Mar 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The araneomorph spider family Palpimanidae is reported from Bolivia for
   the first time. Two new species: Otiothops kathiae and O. naokii are
   described and illustrated based on specimens recently collected in Santa
   Cruz Department. Additionally, Fernandezina pulchra Biraben, 1951
   previously known only from Formosa, in northern Argentina, is newly
   recorded from Santa Cruz, and the female is described for the first
   time. Potential relationships with previously described species are also
   briefly discussed.

DT Article
TI Paleoparasitological results from XVIII century human remains from Rio
   de Janeiro, Brazil.
AU Jaeger, Lauren Hubert
   Taglioretti, Veronica
   Horacio Fugassa, Martin
   Dias, Ondemar
   Neto, Jandira
   Iniguez, Alena Mayo (alena@ioc.fiocruz.br) 
SO Acta Tropica
VL 125
IS 3
PS 282-286
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 16
AB Paleoparasitological studies of the Brazilian colonial period are
   scarce. A paleoparasitological analysis was performed on human remains
   from the archeological site Praca XV Cemetery in Rio de Janeiro, dating
   from the early 18th to 19th Centuries. The samples were obtained from
   the Institute of the Brazilian Archaeology collection, and showed
   evidence of washing and brushing. Sediments were extracted from sacral
   foramina by scraping. Sediments from skulls were used as negative
   paleoparasitological controls. Spontaneous sedimentation method was
   performed prior to microscopic analysis. The results revealed that 8 of
   10 individuals were infected with intestinal helminths and/or Protozoa.
   Eggs of the nematodes Trichuris sp. and Ascaris sp. as well as a single
   taeniid egg were found. Protozoa cysts suggestive of Entamoeba sp. were
   also observed. Trichuris sp. was the most frequent and abundant
   parasite, found in 70% of individuals (26 eggs). The study showed the
   importance of analysis of sediment from human remains preserved in
   museum or scientific collections, even those subjected to a curating
   procedure. The levels of infection revealed here should be considered
   underestimations. This is the first paleoparasitological study from Rio
   de Janeiro city for the Brazilian colonial period and the first report
   of human Taenia sp. in the New World. [copyright] 2012 Elsevier B.V. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Iniguez, Alena Mayo; Fundacao Oswaldo Cruz, Inst Oswaldo Cruz, Rio De
   Janeiro, BR-21045900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM alena@ioc.fiocruz.br
RI INIGUEZ, ALENA M/B-7613-2013
OI INIGUEZ, ALENA M/0000-0002-9788-9533
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0001-706X; 1873-6254
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Ascaris; Entamoeba; Trichuris [Human hosts /  / Palaeoparasitology]
   [Brazil / Rio de Janeiro / ]. 
   Taenia [Human hosts /  / New record; palaeoparasitology] [Land zones /
   New World / ] [Brazil / Rio de Janeiro / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes; Platyhelminths; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Nematoda, Platyhelminthes, Cestoda, Protozoa,
   Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Lobosea, Gymnamoebia, Amoebida
OR Ascaris (Nematoda): [Parasite]. 
   Trichuris (Nematoda): [Parasite]. 
   Taenia (Cestoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Entamoeba (Amoebida): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14908031250

PT J
AN ZOOR14908035150
DT Article
TI Effect of Some Plant Extracts on the Mortality and Hatching of
   Meloidogyne incognita and Globodera rostochiensis Second Stage
   Juveniles.
AU Trifonova, Zlatka (zl.trifonova@abv.bg) 
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 65
IS 1
PS 117-120
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The nematicidal potential of aqueous extracts of tobacco (Nicotiana
   tabacum L.), white falsehellebore (Veratrum album L.), common marigold
   (Tagetes sp.) and common rue (Ruta graveolens L.) against Meloidogine
   incognita (Kofoid et White, 1919) and Globodera rostochiensis (Woll.
   1923) was evaluated in vitro.. The plant extracts showed a marked
   nematicidal activity against second stage juveniles of both nematodes,
   and nematode hatching inhibitory activity against G. rostochiensis
   hatching. They killed juveniles of the root-knot nematode by 26.0% to
   50.4%. Maximum toxic effect (76%-100%) was recorded in the solutions of
   V album and N. tabacum against Globodera rostochiensis. Egg hatching of
   M incognita was by 38.3% to 44.3% compared to the control.
C1 Trifonova, Zlatka; Inst Plant Protect, 35 Panayot Volov Str, Kostinbrod,
   2230, Bulgaria, Bulgaria.
EM zl.trifonova@abv.bg
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Developmental Biology
SN 0324-0770
BD Animals and man; Life cycle and development; Development; Ecology;
   Population dynamics; Abiotic factors
DE Globodera rostochiensis; Meloidogyne incognita [Control /  / juvenile]
   [Hatching /  / ] [Mortality /  / ] [Chemical factors / Plant extracts /
   ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Globodera rostochiensis (Nematoda). 
   Meloidogyne incognita (Nematoda). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14908035150

TI A new species of stick-insect belonging to the genus Trapezaspis
   Redtenbacher, 1908, from Isle of Pines (Phasmatodea, Phasmatidae).
FT Une nouvelle espece de Phasme du genre Trapezaspis Redtenbacher, 1908,
   de l'ile des Pins (Phasmatodea, Phasmatidae).
AU Delfosse, Emmanuel (delfosse@mnhn.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 118
IS 1
PS 15-21
PD Mar 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of stick-insect belonging to the genus Trapezaspis
   Redtenbacher, 1908, from Isle of Pines (Phasmatodea, Phasmatidae). The
   stick-insects of the genus Trapezaspis Redtenbacher, 1908, are
   presented. A new species from New Caledonia is described from a female
   specimen collected on Isle of Pines. An identification key is given to
   recognize the three species of the genus: T. kaiman Redtenbacher, 1908,
   T loricatus Redtenbacher, 1908, and T. pinoruminsulae n. sp.
